TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Mulvihill, I present the following petition from 668 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: University of Queensland: Library Facilities
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The students and staff of the University of Queensland express their dismay at the lack of adequate Federal government funding to our University, which has resulted, inter alia, in the erosion of our Library facilities-we note that:
1. The opening hours of our main Library have been reduced from 93 1/2 hours a week in 1975 to 72 hours a week in 1982.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, concerns defence service homes loans and extended benefits. I welcome the news that a number of repatriation benefits were increased and extended in last week's Budget, but cannot find any increase above $25,000 in the amount available for defence service homes loans. —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It concerns the Sydney businessman Alexander Barton, who might be described as the big Australian battler. As he went to Paraguay five years ago and obtained Paraguayan citizenship, how can he come back to Australia and have permanent domicile here, having divested himself of his Australian citizenship? Is he fish or fowl so far as his citizenship is concerned?

—I am advised that Mr Barton's citizenship was carefully examined in 1978 and 1979. On the evidence then available, the Attorney-General's Department concluded that it could not be assumed that Alexander Barton lost his Australian citizenship, by virtue of the operation of section 17 of the Australian Citizenship Act. He is in possession of a valid Australian passport and, on the basis that he is an Australian citizen, he is not restricted. As I said, that matter was considered on the evidence available in 1978 and 1979. I will refer the question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to see whether he has anything to add or wants to make any further inquiries as of this time.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Not being a lawyer, I have to proceed cautiously. As I understand it, we have had endless consultations on dual citizenship with Italy, Yugoslavia and Greece but we have never had such consultations with Latin American countries. Is there any significance in the fact that we do not give the same recognition to countries in Latin America and other areas with which we have no understandings or agreements? Will our Foreign Affairs and legal people have a look at the question of the Latin American continent so far as dual citizenship is concerned ?

—Senator Mulvihill, and I think all the rest of us, would be very well aware of the problems of dual citizenship. I have not specifically considered in relation to South American countries the question as it has arisen in regard to other countries. That is an aspect of the question that I will also refer to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and ask him to give it special consideration. What needs to be emphasised is not so much the question whether Barton has acquired citizenship of Paraguay but whether he has lost his Australian citizenship.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. As the drought in New South Wales is probably the worst in living memory, if not ever, and extends into Queensland, Victoria and South Australia, I am concerned at Press reports from time to time that often confuse what is being done and can be done by the Commonwealth and the States. It is not a time, after three or four years of drought in many areas, for allegations and distortions. I ask the Minister to outline again the contributions of the States and the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth's current effort and policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Australians generally are becoming increasingly aware of the state of affairs raised by Senator Scott. In many parts of Australia the drought has persisted for a number of years. At the moment it is at its worst on the eastern side of the country. Parts of my own State of Western Australia, particularly the northern wheat belt, were very severely drought stricken for a period of four years. Certainly there are widespread drought conditions in New South Wales and Victoria at the moment, and that is being recognised by all levels of government. Senator Scott is correct in saying that there are now well -established procedures for Commonwealth-State co-operation in the area of drought assistance. This is certainly one of those areas where one wishes to see co-operative action between governments in the common interest.

ANSWER.PARA: The natural disaster assistance measures, which are subscribed to by the Commonwealth, provide that the Commonwealth will apply $3 for each $1 of State expenditure after States have spent a certain base amount. The base amount which is required to be contributed by the States varies according to the size of the States. In New South Wales the base amount is $10 million; in Victoria, $7 million; in Queensland, $4 million; in South Australia and Western Australia, $3 million; in Tasmania, $1.2 million; and in the Northern Territory, $250,000. But the important point is that once those base amounts have been met-and they are amounts set having in mind the revenue resources of the States themselves-the Commonwealth stands ready to make a three to one contribution to further drought relief measures. Those precise measures tend to vary according to the particular conditions, and the longer the drought, often the more assistance is required to ensure that people do not have to leave the land and suffer the final effects of drought.

There is some concern on the part of the States that the base amounts exist at all. In that regard it is perhaps relevant to state that the base amounts were set in 1978-79. There has been no change since that time, so that their relative value compared to State Budgets has considerably declined. I think it would be fiar to say that the Commonwealth does not see itself as being in a static position with respect to drought relief. It accepts that the condition currently is bad. It stands ready to work with the States to ensure that appropriate measures are taken. Cabinet had the matter under consideration this morning, and the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry are very actively involved in considering what appropriate further steps should be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I saw a statement on this matter in, I think, the Canberra Times, or some other newspaper, I have no knowledge as to whether the statement is an accurate report. —At the time. But it is fair to say that no one can predict the demand, say, eight or 10 years ahead. Therefore, it would not be accurate to say that the present power capacity of Tasmania, together with the development of the Bell Bay station, would be able to meet demands of the future . —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. Tin mining represents an important source of employment for the west coast of Tasmania, which produces about 65 per cent of Australia's tin output. As the Minister will be aware, the industry faces severe difficulties because of the sharp fall in the international tin price which has occurred since last February and which has been exacerbated by the imposition of quantitative restrictions under the International Tin Agreement. I understand that these controls are the severest since Australia became a producer member of the International Tin Council. Can the Minister give any indication of when export controls may be removed or at least the level of cutback reduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise because I was distracted and did not hear the opening part of Senator Archer's question.
—You have a copy of the answer, though.
—I have a brief on tin from the Department of Trade and Resources, as I have briefs from every department on most subjects.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We have been through this hardy weekly, hardy monthly and hardy sessional question of so-called questions on notice. The matter has been fully discussed in this chamber.
—We ought to sort it out, too.

—Because of that interjection, I remind the Senate, although it should need no reminder, that the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders looked at this matter and decided that the existing practices should persist. Since there are perennial complaints, let me simply say that every Minister comes into this chamber each day equipped with briefs on major subjects so that he can give factual and helpful answers.

ANSWER.PARA: I have a brief on the tin industry. A serious situation faces the Australian and indeed the world tin industry. Without the buffer stock operations of the International Tin Council there would, without doubt, have been a much more serious slide in the world tin price. I am informed that the Tin Council's Buffer Stock Manager has purchased over 50,000 tonnes of metal, or 25 per cent of the world annual output, in support of the Tin Council floor price. The Commonwealth Government is assisting the Australian tin industry through its contribution of $12m to the financing of the buffer stock operations of the Tin Council.

Owing to the depressed world demand for tin and the continuing level of world production, the very large purchase of tin by the Buffer Stock Manager was insufficient to correct the imbalance and the International Tin Council found it necessary to supplement the buffer stock operations by the introduction of controls to limit the supply of surplus tin coming on to the market. These controls were imposed initially on 27 April of this year. In the absence of these controls there would have been a very grave risk that the International Tin Council's buffer stock operations would not have been able to support the market price at the minimum of the price range under the International Tin Agreement.

The Government is very conscious that the controls are causing hardship to large producers and small miners alike. We have been very concerned that the burden of the controls should be shared fairly. The Department of Trade and Resources has established the Tin Export Control Advisory Committee and the decisions on quota allocations have been taken after advice from that Committee.

Finally, the Government is not in a position to give any indication of when the controls might be removed. However, they are now starting to have an effect and the Government will be seeking to have their severity relaxed as the situation improves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the document from which the Minister quoted be tabled.

Can the Minister advise whether this Government is giving any consideration to waiving this very unpopular and rather unfair tax, particularly in view of the fact that many thousands of tourists, officials and competitors will soon be in Australia to enjoy and participate in the 1982 Brisbane Commonwealth Games? Does the Minister not concur that the removal of this tax for the Games would be a show of good sportsmanship and friendship to our overseas Commonwealth nations visitors and friends who are, after all, coming to Australia to be part of the friendly Games ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There certainly will be a lot of visitors for the friendly Games which will be held in the next couple of months in this country, but no consideration has been given by the Government to any waiving of the departure tax for that occasion. I understand that about $40m will be collected in the next financial year from this tax and any exemptions from it would raise inequities, anomalies and discontent at another level. I can only say that it was introduced in the 1978-79 Budget to assist in revenue raising and to cover costs which relate to international travel.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as I am concerned, there is no proposal before the Government at present to make any change to that tax as a gesture towards the Commonwealth Games. This is not to say that the Commonwealth Games have not attracted many new decisions or a great deal of assistance from the Commonwealth to ensure that they are a success, but no special consideration is under notice for this particular revenue raising measure.

Is it a fact that a senior legal officer was found to have had some 200 companies registered at his home address with the name of his wife as secretary? When did he become aware of these matters? —Senator Walsh would well know from various statements that have been made, from various articles published in the Press and from an item on the Notice Paper today, that I will be making a statement and tabling a report concerning the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I think some of the matters that Senator Walsh has raised will be dealt with in that report. I suggest that he await the tabling of the report and my statement in regard to it. He may then wish to ask further questions.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. If the Attorney- General's statement does not cover the specific matters which I have raised, will he provide answers to those questions and present them to the Senate either later today or tomorrow?
—I think one or two aspects of Senator Walsh's question will not be covered. Whether I can answer them or not is another matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to reports of recent successful experiments in the United Kingdom to alleviate unemployment, where the Government, in conjunction with private enterprise, has established 100 information technology centres to give on-the-job training at a small salary to 15 to 19-year-olds on computers and word processors. In view of the need for skills to obtain employment and the need to understand developments in this area , I ask: Will the Government give consideration to the running of a pilot scheme in Canberra to evaluate the benefit of such a scheme with a view to its being extended throughout Australia?

—I am not familiar with the scheme which the honourable senator tells us has been undertaken by the United Kingdom Government to alleviate the problem of youth unemployment and, by the sound of it, the problem of transition from school to work. It would be well known to honourable senators since the bringing down of the Budget that the Commonwealth has allocated considerably greater funds this year to the various programs which are in the same area as the program mentioned by Senator Reid in her question. I think the increase in funding is something like 25 per cent and well over 100,000 young Australians will benefit from the various programs which are conducted by the relevant departments. I will refer the question to Mr Macphee and his Department for examination to see whether it does offer us some further avenue of assistance in that important area.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Liberal Party in New South Wales recalled nominations for the Senate? Are those endorsements to be decided this Sunday? Is it a fact that the endorsements will be for a full team of six?
—The question is out of order.
—If that is the case, is this a firm indication that there will be an early election-and this brings the question back into order-and that that election will take place after a double dissolution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question, I should indicate in the first place that I am a member of the New South Wales State Executive of the Liberal Party and therefore I can say that I have no knowledge at all of any action by the Executive to change in any way the decision that was made recently in the renomination of the half Senate team. However, this morning I received an informal message that apparently the headquarters of the Liberal Party is considering what steps might be taken should there be a double dissolution. I repeat: 'should there be'. There has been, to my knowledge, nothing at all in that regard. The information I got this morning could be thoroughly wrong, so I cannot comment on that.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to make it clear that there is no decision by this Government and no indication by this Government of any intention to do other than run its full course. On the other hand, in view of the present behaviour of the Senate, one could be tempted, of course, in this regard. It would be a strange thing indeed if both the Australian Labor Party and the Government parties did not contemplate procedures for electing a full team of six if there were to be a double dissolution. That is the only situation of which I know and nobody should draw any speculative conclusions from it. I can understand, of course, the Labor Party's anxiety neurosis should it in fact have to face the umpire.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education aware of the campaign currently being conducted by the New South Wales Teachers Federation based on claims regarding the level of State and Commonwealth government support of government schools? Has there been a reduction of financial support by the Commonwealth for government schools? Are funds being diverted from government schools and redirected to the non-government sector?

—I had occasion a week or two ago to talk to the Council of the New South Wales Teachers Federation. It has a belief-an incorrect belief- that this Government is not funding government schools as it used to fund them. It has an incorrect belief that this Government does not support government schools. Both those beliefs are incorrect, and since they underpin a rather nasty campaign going on at the present time-a campaign, by the way, based upon a levy on every member of the New South Wales Teachers Federation-it is worth putting the facts correctly. The 1976 calendar year was the last year of Labor funding for government schools. I can advise Senator Martin and honourable senators that last year, this year and next year, the Fraser Government has provided and will provide more recurrent Commonwealth support in real terms for government schools than was provided in the last Labor Government Budget. I repeat: More recurrent support was provided and will be provided in real terms for government schools than was provided in the last year of Labor. On that fact alone the rather nasty campaign of the New South Wales Teachers Federation falls . It is incorrect. I find it very distressing to have a campaign mounted like this when the claims simply are not correct.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education, who is still No. 1 on the Senate ticket until Sunday. Has the Minister viewed a letter from the honourable member for Bendigo, Mr Bourchier, in which he indicates that the former Minister for Education had agreed to the continuation of a two-year engineering course at the Bendigo College of Advanced Education? Did the Minister's predecessor agree to its continuation? Will the Minister approve the proposed arrangement between the Bendigo and Ballarat colleges of advanced education?

—I thank Senator Robert Ray for his recognition that I am No. 1 on the Senate ticket in New South Wales. I hope to remain in that position. At the time the re-arrangement of the Ministry took place in May, Mr Fife, my predecessor, had before him a proposition in relation to the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. Senator Robert Ray will be aware that an engineering course was available there. The Commonwealth indicated that it was necessary that new arrangements be made in relation to this course. The agreed position for which reconsideration was sought was that one year of applied science, which would count towards an engineering degree, was to be carried out at Bendigo while the other three years were to be carried out elsewhere. What was sought was that two years of applied science at Bendigo might count towards an engineering degree, with two years being finished off at some other college such as Ballarat or elsewhere. I am aware of the representations that were made. I had made an initial assessment of the facts but I am re-examining the matter. If it is possible within the guidelines laid down by the Commonwealth to meet the request that two years of applied science carried out at Bendigo College should count towards an engineering degree, even if that degree is completed elsewhere, and if it can be done within existing funding and meets with the approval of Victoria, then it is something that I would want to examine very carefully. I am seeking advice on the matter from the Tertiary Education Commission.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to that part of the Minister's statement made on Budget night concerning social security programs, in which he said that there are some areas within the welfare system in which inflation has caused special problems for particular groups of people and, as such, the Budget's aim is to overcome these particular problems. I ask whether the uniform wage restraint presently being asked for by the Government would result in further worthwhile relief for these groups in particular and would help to overcome these problems recurring in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has correctly quoted part of the statement which I made on Budget night about the welfare budget. I did point out that inflation has caused special problems for some groups of people. It is probably fair to say that inflation causes problems for everybody but not least-perhaps most-for those on low incomes and those on fixed incomes. It is not, however, only in the field of income security that there are particular problems. If one looks at the problems faced by those who are running institutions for the aged one will find plenty of examples of organisations which have been in severe financial difficulty because of the increases in their wage costs. A delegation saw me in Sydney earlier this year about the cost of running hostels for the aged. It produced figures for the last 12 months. The wage costs in four organisations had increased by, I think, 32 per cent in two organisations, 36 per cent or 38 per cent in another and 48 per cent in another. That, of course, makes the operation of those organisations extremely difficult. That is why the additional provision for personal care subsidy which was announced in the Budget was backdated to the beginning of July.

ANSWER.PARA: Probably, however, the most substantial point to be made in response to the honourable senator's question is with respect to those who are on low incomes. Most social security beneficiaries and pensioners are protected against changes in the cost of living by twice-yearly indexation. There are some important elements of the system-in particular, benefits paid to the single unemployed and the young unemployed-which are not indexed benefits. Those benefits have been subject to indexation level adjustments in the Budget.

I think most people are coming round to a realisation that inflation poses a very large problem and that wage restraint is an important element in bringing inflation under control. The attitude which has been adopted by members of parliament-certainly on this side of the chamber and I think probably also on the other side-in showing a high degree of wage restraint this year is some mark of that. A substantial number of companies have come to arrangements with their employees over recent months to provide for relatively low wage increases- certainly low compared with those of the past 12 months or so. I mention companies such as Leyland Motor Corporation of Australia Ltd, Qantas Airways Ltd , ICI Australia Ltd, Kennecott Explorations (Australia) Ltd, the Myer Emporium Ltd, Grace Bros Pty Ltd, G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd and Wormald International (Aust .) Pty Ltd as a group which has tried to give some lead in this area.

From a purely welfare point of view I believe there would be many benefits if we could achieve a period of wage restraint. There would be obvious benefits to those people who have the running of institutions as their responsibility and who find ever increasing wage costs a very substantial burden. In particular, I think all low income Australians would accept that anything which does something to reduce the rising costs which make their lives difficult is something which should be encouraged not only by government but also by the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to the announcement in the Budget that the disability pension of 100 per cent general rate will be restored for the pulmonary tuberculosis veterans who lost it on 2 November 1978. Since the Government has now recognised that it has unjustly deprived those veterans of that particular benefit, why has it not also decided to pay them as from that date instead of from 6 January next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision that was taken in 1978 was, as we have discussed in the Senate quite often, against the background of advances which had been made in medical science at that time and which, as Senator Macklin would recognise, are applicable today. It was taken against a background of people recovering from disease. Veterans had nothing taken away from them if they had their disease properly assessed as a disability resulting from war service. At that time, as Senator Macklin would know, many tuberculosis veterans were reassessed and received higher disability pensions as a result. Accordingly, the Government at the time felt quite justified in taking the action that it did.

ANSWER.PARA: In restoring the pension to the 100 per cent general rate in the latest Budget decision, the Government considered representations that had been made by all sections of the ex-service community since that time with a view to having restored to those people the benefit which they deemed affected their lifestyles at critical times of their lives. Consequently, as those people get older, it is felt justifiable that they should have that benefit restored. In both circumstances the decisions have been justified in terms of considerations of the moment. The retrospectivity to which Senator Macklin referred in his question is not a matter which the Government felt the need to consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations: Is it true that largely as a result of the recommendations of the razor gang the staff of the Commonwealth Employment Service was reduced during the last financial year? Is it also true that in the same period the number of people registered with the CES rose by seven per cent and the number of job seekers in Western Australia alone rose by 40 per cent? Have thousands of career advice pamphlets had to be destroyed because there is no one to distribute them? Are many work information centres without up to date material?

—The question seems to be squarely based on a briefing note I have from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations headed 'Topical Issue No. 11'. It contains a great deal of material and I have no wish to burden the Senate with what would amount to a ministerial statement rather than a reply. I will take a few very brief points and perhaps provide additional information later for the honourable senator. There has been an 8 per cent staff reduction over the 12 months to June 1982. The number of registrations in June 1982 compared with registrations in June 1981 shows an increase in Victoria of 7 per cent. I do not have the figure for Western Australia but I have no reason to dispute the figure put forward by Senator Giles. However, I will have it checked . The variation from June 1981 to June 1982 in the number of unemployed looking for full time work, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, shows an increase in Victoria of 18.5 per cent, the comparable national figure being 26.2 per cent. There will be some reductions in staff due to the Job Bank, which will produce more effective and efficient methods of work in the Commonwealth Employment Service offices, but I know of no suggestion that there have been particular difficulties in the Commonwealth Employment Service because of the changes in ceiling which were effected last year. As I have said, the matter is one on which I have available a fair amount of detailed information. I will examine the question carefully and as soon as possible will give a considered but reasonably concise reply to the honourable senator.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology: In view of the extreme drought conditions that are affecting so many rural areas of Australia, is the Minister able to say what is the present state of the art of cloud seeding? Is any action being taken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in an endeavour to encourage rain? I know that the Minister is full of scientific knowledge, but if by some chance she is not able to inform the Senate now, will she undertake to do so as soon as possible, as the matter of rain-or lack of it-is of great concern in most rural areas of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I undertake to refer the question to the Minister for Science and Technology and obtain early information on the present position with regard to cloud seeding. At present I cannot give up to date advice on the matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED VISIT TO AUSTRALIA BY MR HORTA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to you, Mr President, follows the question asked earlier by Senator Sibraa concerning the refusal of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to issue a visa to Mr Ramos Horta to enable him to appear before the all-party Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Will you consider whether the Minister and his Department are in breach of privilege of this House, or of a committee of this House, and report thereon to the Senate? Surely you will agree that the Committee has the right of access to special witnesses and should not be prevented from hearing their evidence, particularly as the invitation to Mr Horta was a pauper's invitation; that is, he would have to meet all his own expenses to come here.
—I will endeavour to obtain a reply for the honourable senator. He will appreciate that I will need to obtain advice on such a technical question, but I will respond in due time.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, relates to the work and future plans of Australia's Human Rights Commission which commenced operations in December 1981. Because of the important role which it was envisaged the Commission would play in the advancement of human rights in Australia, I ask whether it is correct, firstly, that there are no plans to locate any of the 28 officers who have commenced, or will shortly commence, work with the Commission outside of Canberra; secondly, that the Queensland and Western Australian governments have applied pressure to prevent the opening of offices in those two States; thirdly, that one human rights commissioner recently told a meeting in Perth that so far 60 per cent to 70 per cent of complaints could not be handled by the Commission as they related to State matters? If this statement is correct, in the light of our obligatons under the Covenant, what action is the Federal Government taking to persuade State governments to establish State human rights commissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen has asked some questions which call for a rather detailed reply. I propose to answer them only generally and to provide him, and the Senate of course, with a detailed answer which I have but which would take rather a long time to read out. As to his first question, the present establishment of the Commission is 25 full time and 5 part time office staff, and I understand that the Commission is now working at that full strength. Those staff members are located in Canberra but, of course, some spend a good deal of time out of Canberra investigating complaints. The answer to the second question in regard to the Queensland and West Australian governments applying pressure to prevent the opening of offices in those two States is no. The Commission is intending in the near future to appoint a part time representative in Perth. Of course, the Human Rights Commission Act does contemplate that arrangements will be made with the States to have offices operating jointly with them in each capital city. Although none of those offices has yet been established, that is certainly still the policy of the Commission and it is well known to the States.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the third question-that 60 or 70 per cent of complaints could not be handled as they relate to State matters-I understand that this was so in the first one or two months of the operations of the Commission but a recent analysis shows that of complaints up to 30 June, 25 per cent were outside the jurisdiction of the Commission because they related to State matters and a further 30 per cent were outside its jurisdiction because they related to rights not covered by the Commission's charter. As to the final question, in regard to what action the Federal Government will take to persuade States to establish State human rights commissions, at this stage the Government does not believe that there is sufficient evidence to indicate that the States will not co- operate with the Commonwealth's Human Rights Commission.

As I said, I think the Senate will be satisfied by the detailed answer that I will provide that the urgent problem that Senator Missen fears, and which he expressed in his question, does not exist. The Commonwealth believes that these are matters for the States to decide. A ministerial meeting on human rights takes place whenever the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General meets. There is a good deal of discussion about various problems concerning our international obligations at these meetings in respect of proposed and existing covenants and conventions and, all in all, in the last couple of years there has been a very much greater recognition of the international obligations that Australia has assumed, not only by way of the Federal Government but also by way of State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services and concerns the role that the Australian Federal Police will play at the forthcoming Commonwealth Games. Will members of the Australian Federal Police be sworn into the Queensland police force as special constables? Will any members of the Australian Federal Police be used to implement the much criticised Commonwealth Games Act in Queensland? Can the Minister guarantee that the Australian Federal Police will not be used at the Commonwealth Games to deny any person's right of peaceful protest? Will the Australian Federal Police be available to be used to ensure the security of National Aboriginal Conference members who will be meeting in Brisbane at that time?

—Senator Ryan has asked a very detailed question on a number of matters. I have only very sketchy information in respect of some parts of it. All I am able to confirm is that the Australian Federal Police will be assisting the Queensland police in various matters to do with the Commonwealth Games. In the light of that situation, I think that the best thing to do is to refer the question to the Minister and see whether I can obtain an early reply today for Senator Ryan.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer and refer to the change in the Budget concerning primary producers. Previously their diesel fuel was exempt from tax; now they will pay the full price and be subject to a rebate. Can the Minister indicate how long it will take the average primary producer to receive his rebate in respect of diesel products used on the farm? May we have an assurance that, whatever the time, it will take the minimum time possible to process the relevant forms that will be required under the new procedures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think that the Department of Industry and Commerce is dealing with the legislation relating to this matter. I understand that periodical payments will be made to those who claim under the rebate system and that, in drafting the procedures and the legislation, every attempt is being made to ensure a minimum of delay in the payment of the rebate. I would need to get further information on that matter. Of course, it will all be available when the legislation comes before Parliament and willl set out the procedures, which have had a great deal of detailed consideration by the Government, to ensure that there is no undue delay after the system has been set in place for the rebate to take effect. Perhaps I will be in a position a little later to give some information on that, but I can assure the honourable senator only that the Government is considering the procedures to eliminate any unnecessary delay in payment of the rebate once the system is established.

—I ask a supplementary question. May we have an assurance that the necessary legislation will be expedited through the Parliament? As I understand it, the changed procedures are operative from day one.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill concerned is one of the Budget Bills. It will be dealt with as soon as possible in this session of Parliament. As I say, a lot of consideration has been given to the matter of obviating unnecessary delays through bureaucratic procedures. However, until the Bill is ready I am unable to do more than say just that I am aware that a lot of discussion has been undertaken on this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Attorney-General's attention has been drawn to the comments of Mr Bruce Brown, the magistrate in the so-called social security conspiracy case, on the role in the case of ex-Detective Chief Inspector Donald Thomas, with a view to proceedings being taken against him for-I quote the magistrate's words:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . conspiracy to pervert the course of justice or for perjury, or for both.

As it is two months since Mr Brown made this statement and talked about the conduct being of the highest impropriety, what action has the Minister taken, or what action does the Minister or the Government intend to take in this matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention certainly was drawn to the comments by the magistrate, Mr Brown, in the social security case, before the charges were withdrawn and then when they were withdrawn. The particular comments Senator Grimes has raised are those concerning the conduct of Detective Chief Inspector Thomas. As I said, I was well aware of these comments. The matter has been referred to the Crown Solicitor, and the papers are being examined with a view to seeing what action should or can be taken in regard to them. I have spoken to the Crown Solicitor about the matter. At this stage I do not think I can add anything more, other than to say that it is being examined and I am awaiting a report on the matter.

—My question follows one asked earlier today by Senator Archer of the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. I ask : First, how can a free enterprise government join and support a socialist marketing operation, such as the International Tin Council, instead of letting market forces apply? Secondly, if the Government is going to be party to such a marketing system, in the interests of fairness and justice to all tin producers across the nation, will it reduce considerably the disproportionate share of the present quota held by the Renison tin company, which has tricked the Government into giving it a far larger quota than it deserves, thereby denying many small miners a livelihood? Thirdly, does the Minister realise that one of the consequences of being a party to the International Tin Council is that many tin miners simply cannot sell their tin at any price at all and, therefore, have no income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question and this answer are against the background of a world recession in which the demand for tin has fallen. There has been some perception that there needs to be some orderly process to keep tin mining operations going. In response to Senator MacGibbon, I am aware that a number of the smaller miners feel that they are being prejudiced because they had not been seen to be active in any dimension in the mining business in the past. Therefore, they feel that they should have consideration. I understand that that matter has been considered by the Government. The general question itself comes under the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Trade and Resources, in another place. Since Senator MacGibbon asked specific questions I will direct them to Mr Anthony and seek a further reply.

—I direct my question to Senator Chaney wearing his three hats- as Minister representing the Ministers for Industry and Commerce, Primary Industry and Employment and Industrial Relations. As all of these departments have an involvement in the developing unemployment crises in the south-east of South Australia, particularly in the Mount Gambier and Millicent area, I ask the Minister: What action, if any, has each of these departments taken to overcome the unemployment problem, plus the short time which is now being worked by the timber mills in the area due to timber being imported from New Zealand and the United States of America? Has the Government received any representation from the South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin, for assistance in preventing the cellulose paper mill at Millicent from closing, with the resultant loss of more than 300 jobs? If no representation has been received, will the Minister take immediate action to ascertain what is required to prevent the closure from taking place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little disappointed that Senator McLaren left out my fourth and primary hat of Minister for Social Security because I think that even the Department of Social Security has done something to contribute to the solution of the problems about which he is very properly concerned. The concern that we have about the employment situation is in part reflected in the programs which are administered by my Department which, as well as having a welfare impact, have an impact on activity. I would point to the announcements which were made a month or two ago with respect to welfare housing. The increased allocation in that field is an important contribution to all areas of Australia. I would point to the announcements which I made a couple of weeks ago with respect to the Aged and Disabled Persons Accommodation Program and the Handicapped Persons Assistance Program, where additional capital funds are being made available this year and next year, not only for the welfare benefits that that will bring but also because it will result in some increased activity in areas of the economy which are certainly underutilised at present.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations is concerned, I mentioned earlier in Question Time the large increase in the allocation for training and income support programs for the young. There is a whole variety of things in the current Budget which acknowledge the need for increased activity in Australia at a time when the private sector is less active. The Bicentennial Road Development Program which was announced, and which is not one of my responsibilities, is a program which will not only do something to meet the real social need for better communications in many of the more difficult parts of Australia but also lead to an increase in physical activity at a time when I am sure it will be welcomed by Senator McLaren and all other honourable senators.

The timber industry is a matter which has been the subject, I know, of a series of representations from the honourable senator and, indeed, from the industry. There have been meetings between the Minister for Industry and Commerce and representatives of the industry. I have a note of a meeting which he had at the beginning of August with representatives of the Australian Softwood Producers Council on the position of the industry and the Council's request for a reference to the Temporary Assistance Authority covering sawn softwood timber. He has also met with representatives of the South East Trades and Labor Council of South Australia on the same matters and therefore the Minister is fully aware of the concerns which were raised in the latter part of Senator McLaren's question.

After studying a report from the Department of Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch reached a decision that the most appropriate action would be for the permanent heads of the relevant Australian and New Zealand departments to discuss the matter. Those discussions are currently under way. That was because of the impact of the New Zealand industry on the industry which is the concern of Senator McLaren and which he is purporting to represent here today. I will see whether there is more up to date information available on the initiatives which have been taken by Sir Phillip Lynch in this area and whether there are other particular departmental activities that can be pointed to. But in general I would point to the Budget as expressing the Commonwealth Government's concern for the whole of Australia in the important area of employment and to our different attitude to capital expenditure in this Budget and, indeed, at the time of the Premiers Conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister whether he had had any representation from the Premier of South Australia about the proposed closure of the cellulose mill at Millicent with the loss of some 300 jobs?
—I have no information in my brief on that matter and I have no independent recollection of it. I will have to check that point and let Senator McLaren have a further reply.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time last Thursday, Senator Robertson asked whether I could arrange for the Senate to be provided with a brief report on the construction progress on the new Parliament House, and also arrange for a visit to the site. I am pleased to advise that arrangements are being made for interested senators to visit the site and inspect the work during the first week in September.

INTERJECT.PARA: In relation to construction progress, I have been provided with a brief statement on the current status of the project, which I now present for the information of honourable senators. In September last year, approval was given by both Houses of the Parliament for the third declared stage of the project. This approval permitted the commencement of work on the construction and fitting out of the new Parliament House, together with the construction of on site access roads, parking areas, other facilities and the landscaping of the site. Authorisation for this work was given on the basis of the schematic design, which was a major design phase submitted to Parliament by the Parliament House Construction Authority. Since that time considerable work has been undertaken in finalising the design and in actual construction. The motivation for early construction of the major underground car parks has been the large covered storage and workshops they will provide during the remainder of the construction phase and the need to complete the access road around the building complex.

Construction work is also well advanced on the main entrance to the building, with the grand verandah and foyer taking recognisable form. Construction will be undertaken progressively through the central core of the building, with a start already having been made on foundation work for both the reception hall and members' hall. Work has also begun on the House of Representatives chamber which is located to the east of the central core of the building and construction will move progressively to the east to enable construction of the House of Representatives office areas. A similiar process will be adopted for the Senate chamber and offices.

In this way three main work faces will be maintained throughout the building construction phase. The main structure is programmed to be largely completed by the end of 1985. Fit out and commissioning of the building will continue through to 1987. The build-up in construction activity is reflected in the work force on the site which now exceeds 450 and will continue to increase to the maximum employment figure of approximately 1,200. I believe the best way to appreciate the progress of construction is to visit the site and I hope honourable senators will take the opportunity to visit the site early in September.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time today Senator Scott asked me a question about the Commonwealth and drought relief. I was aware at that time that the Prime Minister was communicating with Premiers but I did not wish to say anything until I could confirm that in fact he had done so. In light of the importance of this matter to honourable senators from many States I think I should advise the Senate that the Prime Minister has taken up with the State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory the impact of the continuing severe drought throughout Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: After pointing out that the Commonwealth has, over the past three years, provided $100m to the States for drought relief under the existing arrangements , the Prime Minister has gone on to express his grave concern about the effect of continued drought conditions and has asked for a meeting between relevant State ministers and the Commonwealth Minister for Primary Industry as soon as possible on the subject of drought relief. I mention that to honourable senators because, as I said before, I think it is a matter which is of great importance to the constituents of many of those who are in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Early today Senator Ryan asked me a question in connection with the Australian Federal Police and its activities in Queensland during the Commonwealth Games. I am unable to give answers to all the questions which Senator Ryan addressed. However, I can indicate that the Federal Police will be providing assistance for VIP protection, airport security, bomb search and mail screening. These are functions which Federal Police would normally undertake. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.
