SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report on Namibia is tabled against a background of conflicting trends. On the one hand, there is the optimistic note of Press reports in recent weeks which indicate a Namibia settlement could be near. On the other hand, there is the South African incursion into Angola of a fortnight ago to strike at South West Africa People's Organisation bases, a move which could further delay a settlement. There have been conflicting explanations of the South African incursion. One view is that South Africa timed its assault to further delay a settlement. Another view is that both South Africa and SWAPO are seeking to gain maximum advantage prior to the ceasefire which would accompany any settlement. Before the incursion, a settlement had seemed imminent, and there had been Press speculation that a ceasefire involving SWAPO and South African forces might be in force within the month. Whether a settlement does eventuate in the near future remains to be seen. If a settlement is achieved, it will end one of the longest-running international disputes to have been before the United Nations since it was formed in 1945. Until the incursion, the last major obstacle to a settlement was a South African demand that a ceasefire in Namibia be accompanied by a withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola. Cuban troops were invited into Angola in 1975 by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola-MPLA- Government to counter a South African incursion and to help the MPLA in its civil war with the other major group in Angola, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, UNITA. Cuban troops have remained since.

South Africa argues that the continued presence of an estimated 20,000 Cuban troops in Angola during a Namibian transition to independence could encourage SWAPO to continue its guerrilla war should it lose independence elections. South Africa also is concerned at what it sees as a growing Soviet influence in the region. It appears to be using the issue of Namibian independence to try to reduce that influence by making a Cuban withdrawal its condition for an end to the guerrilla war. SWAPO has rejected the South African linkage of a Cuban withdrawal from Angola with the issue of Namibian independence.

Angola has stated that it will not ask Cuban forces to leave until Namibia is independent and until South African cross-border raids stop. Whether South Africa or SWAPO and Angola will modify their positions on the Cuban issue remains to be seen. South Africa is under Western pressure to agree to a settlement while SWAPO is under similar pressure from the front line states. The front line states, particularly Angola, would like the Namibia issue settled so that they can concentrate on their economic and other problems.

Like South Africa, some of the front line states such as Zimbabwe would also like to see a reduction in Soviet influence in the region. They see the continuation of the guerrilla war as likely only to increase Soviet influence and further destabilise southern Africa. This was a point made strongly by Prime Minister Mugabe only a matter of weeks ago to the Australian delegation of which Senator Young, Senator Hill and I were members. It could be argued that South African intransigence so far in refusing to grant independence to Namibia has in fact assisted in the spread of Soviet influence in the region. If South Africa had granted independence sooner, or at least granted blacks in Namibia full equality with whites, the major nationalist organisation, SWAPO, would not have had to resort to force to try to achieve those ends. SWAPO might not have had to go to the Soviet Union for arms and other assistance and Angola might no longer have felt the need to maintain Cuban troops. My impression after speaking to President Kaunda and Prime Minister Mugabe, amongst others, including SWAPO, is that there exists an unofficial understanding that with a settlement in Namibia, Angola will in fact phase out Cuban troops in that country.

The Committee considers that for South Africa to link the issue of the Cubans in Angola with a Namibia settlement will only further delay independence for that territory. It further considers that South African policies in the region serve only to increase openings for the Soviet Union to expand its influence rather than minimise it. What is happening is that the events in Namibia are linked to events in Angola, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. If South Africa continues to ignore African nationalism and confuse it with communism, and also continues to try to destabilise the countries of southern Africa, it will import the very thing it fears most; that is, communism. If southern Africa goes up in flames the biggest loser inevitably will be South Africa.

The Committee's report on Namibia traces the history of the Namibia dispute from its origins in a League of Nations mandate to the situation obtaining at the beginning of this month. It considers a number of political, social and economic issues, including the controversy over the status of Walvis Bay, and examines Australian involvement and interest in the territory. The report is a comprehensive one and is the result of some three years' deliberations by the Sub-Committee on Middle Eastern and African Affairs and its predecessor, the Sub -Committee on Southern Africa. The report on Namibia follows the Sub-Committee's study of the Gulf region, tabled in May of this year and its report on Zimbabwe, tabled in 1980.

Mr Deputy President, I realise that there are limitations of time today and that this report will be debated on Thursday. I certainly do not wish to pre- empt the report of the parliamentary delegation to Africa. However, events in southern Africa are extremely volatile and notoriously badly reported in Australia and I believe that a full debate on these matters would be in order as soon as possible. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE GOVERNMENT CLOTHING AND ORDNANCE FACTORIES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Bendigo Ordnance Factory: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator DURACK

TALK.START.PARA: —(Western Australia)-For the information of honourable senators I table the Government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories on the future of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, and I seek leave to make a statement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator DURACK

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement has already been presented to the House of Representatives. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The Senate Select Committee presented its report on the future of the Ordnance Factory Bendigo to the Parliament on 9 March, 1982. This statement responds on behalf of the Government to that report.

On 7 July, 1982, the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) announced that the Government had decided that the Ordnance Factory Bendigo would continue as a Government Factory. The Government made that decision after considering a single expression of interest for the lease of the factory following public advertisements inviting expressions of interest for the sale or lease of the factory with a closing date of 11 June, 1982.

Honourable senators will recall the history of this matter which, however, I will shortly recapitulate. One of the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions announced on 30 April, 1981 was that the Government proposed to endeavour to sell the Ordnance Factory Bendigo as a going concern to private enterprise. In consequence of that decision expressions of interest fro the acquisition of the Factory were invited with a closing date of 12 June, 1981, which was later extended to 8 July, 1981.

Before that process could be completed, the Senate resolved to refer the Government's decision to sell the Governmen Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. Subsequently, on 23 September, 1981, the Senate resolved that a Select Committee be established to report on the future of the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo. As I earlier mentioned, the Senate Select Committee presented its report on the Ordnance Factory Bendigo on 9 March, 1982. It is still to present its report on the future of the Government Clothing Factory, Coburg.

The members of the Committee were divided in their views on the future of the Ordnance Factory. Senator Martyr (Chairman) and Senator Crichton-Browne recommended: the sale of the factory as a going concern; that if efforts to sell failed then the possibility of sale of various sections of the factory as 'going concerns' be investigated; and if all efforts failed then the operation of the factory be wound down and closed with appropriate assistance to be given to apprentices and employees thereby displaced. The other two members of the Committee, Senator Button and Senator Siddons, dissented.

On 17 March, 1982, the Prime Minister, (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in answer to a question in the House from the honourable member for Bendigo, Mr Bourchier, expressed the Government's position in the light of the Senate Committee's report in this way:

I have seen the report on the future of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The Government will be looking at the report quite closely. I note that the main part of the report recommends that the Ordnance Factory still be sold. That is consistent with the Review of Commonwealth Functions recommendation of a year ago and the Government's efforts since then which in a sense had been suspended during the Senate Committee inquiry. The Government will evaluate the various proposals, or offers of tenders and, when that process is finished, it will come to a final decision as to whether or not the factory will be sold.

The Government would much prefer that the factory could be sold to private enterprise so that new investment could be attracted to Bendigo and to the Ordnance Factory. This would provide opportunities for expanded activity. More money would flow through the factory and into the city.

In respect of the Committee's recommendation that if the factory could not be sold it should be closed down the Prime Minister advised the honourable member that the Government did not accept that part of the Committee's recomendations. The Prime Minister said:

The Government believed that its reaction to that part of the recommendations ought to be made known quickly so that the concern that would be felt as a result of that recommendation could be put completely and absolutely at rest.
The Prime Minister assured the House of the future of the factory by saying:

Having examined all the options and in particular the impact on Bendigo, the Government, if it is not successful in its efforts to sell the Ordnance Factory to a vigorous and vital private enterprise concern, will continue to operate the factory as a government operation.

The Prime Minister visited Bendigo on 22 March, 1982, and, in the company of the honourable member for Bendigo, addressed the factory employees and repeated that assurance. Thus, in order to bring the matter to a conclusion, the Government decided to explore the interest of private enterprise in taking on the operation of the factory, in the light of the Senate Committee Report, by re-advertising for expressions of interest for the purchase or lease of the factory.

As I advised the Senate at the beginning of this statement, the Government has decided that the factory will continue as a Government factory. An expression of interest was received from one company, Vickers' Australia Ltd., to lease the factory. The Government did not consider that the company's proposal met the Government's requirement for the future operation of the factory or the commitments which had been made by the Government to the people of Bendigo.

In his public announcement of the Government's decision on 7 July, 1982, Mr Viner emphasised the responsibilities that lay ahead of the Government, the management of the factory and the whole work force in assuring the future of the Factory. Mr Viner said:

It remains for factory management and staff to work together with the Government to demonstrate that the Ordnance Factory Bendigo has an important part to play in the field of defence support and that cost and performance achievements in the future will justify the Government's decision to continue its operation as a Government factory.

Mr President, in view of this background Mr Viner has, since undertaking the responsibilities of the new Department of Defence Support, been concerned to remove the uncertainties about the future of the factory and put in train action which will allow the employees to look ahead with growing confidence.

Prior to the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government had agreed that implementation of recommendations contained in a Joint Management Review of the Munitions Factories should proceed. With the exception of Ordnance Factory Bendigo and the Australian Government Clothing Factory, the recommended changes in upper structure positions in the factories have been implemented and staffing of the positions is proceeding. Consequential changes for junior management are in hand. Now that the Government has made its decision to retain the Ordnance Factory Bendigo, action is in hand to implement the necessary management changes in that factory.

I would like to take this opportunity to indicate the investment being made by the Government in the factory and actions being taken to establish a better workload for it. In the 1982-83 Budget, expenditure of $947,000 is provided for. This includes $80,000 for computing facilities, $190,000 for rationalisation of production facility for 500lb bombs, plant acquisitions of $200,000 and repairs and maintenance of $477,000. Such expenditure of nearly $1m in this financial year is an emphatic demonstration of the Government's readiness to meet the commitment made to the factory's employees, to the civic authorities and the people of Bendigo by the Prime Minister, Mr Viner and the member for Bendigo, Mr Bourchier.

But more than that, there is included in the works design list of the Department of Transport and Construction for this year provision for a new electroplating facility at an estimated cost of $550,000, and it is planned to call tenders for extensions to the metrology laboratory-a key facility in meeting the precision requirements of ordnance manufacture-in March 1983 at an estimated cost of $415,000.

The factory has budgeted for 310,000 man hours of work in the current financial year, being an increase of 50,000 hours in defence work and an overall increase of 18,000 hours over the 1981-82 workload. The future of the factory is really dependent upon the volume of defence and commercial work which can be directed or attracted to it under the nation's defence program or the guidelines for engaging in commercial activity. Thus the workload of the factory will respond to the overall national defence effort in time of peace or the competitiveness of the factory to obtain commercial work.

Nevertheless one of the most significant prospects for increased workload, as well as opportunity to acquire and apply new and advance technology, lies with Project Hamel. This project is designed to equip the Army with the British 105mm light gun as a key weapon over the next decade. It is anticipated that the Ordnance Factory Bendigo will manufacture a significant proportion of components and the gun will be assembled at Bendigo.

An executive engineer from the factory will play a significant role in the furtherance of this project. Dr J. Barclay has been selected to fill a new post in the United Kingdom as the liaison engineer for the project. Dr Barclay will leave Australia on 16 September, 1982, to take up a three year posting. In another effort to open up new opportunities for Bendigo a factory representative has recently visited the United States to discuss the possibilty of sub-contract work with United States firms. Discussions have taken place at officer level with the Victorian Government. It is hoped that the Victorian Government will be true to its public statements that it wishes to direct more of the major engineering work of its own instrumentalities to Bendigo.

Mr President, whilst the Government would have been happy to have been able to sell or lease the factory to a private enterprise purchaser, able to put new investment into the factory, expand the commercial opportunities for the factory within Australia and overseas and to secure and expand employment at Bendigo, it was not, in the events which have happened since the announcement of the decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions in April 1981, possible to achieve such a sale or lease within a reasonable time and with appropriate guarantees. Nevertheless, I am sure honourable members, the factory work force and the people of Bendigo will understand that, by the actions which I have related, the Government will now do all that it reasonably can to improve the efficiency of the factory and expand the workload of it and thereby improve the prospects of its future operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Situated in a 61-acre site in a leafy suburb in the provincial city of Bendigo is a factory which has become a monument to the incompetence of the Fraser Government. It is the subject of this report. It symbolises incompetence in action over a period of 18 months at considerable cost to the taxpayer, at considerable cost to the people of Bendigo and, ultimately, at cost to the Fraser Government in terms of the Bendigo electorate when the next Federal election is held. In April 1981, the Government made a decision about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory as part of the so-called razor gang decisions. I briefly refer the Senate to the decision that was made. In that decision, part of the so-called Review of Commonwealth Functions, the razor gang stated:

In the view of the Government, activities of a commercial kind are generally best performed in the private sector, where they are open to greater influence from consumers and to the disciplines of competition . . . We propose to offer for sale as a going concern the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo . . .

I suppose it is rather late in the day to draw attention to the fact that influence of consumers and competition in the production of defence equipment do not exist in Australia-at least, one hopes so. I thought that the only recipients of defence equipment in Australia were the Australian military forces . I hope there are no other recipients which would make this factory receptive to the wishes of consumers. Of course, the Ordnance Factory has gone the same way as have many of the other establishments mentioned in the razor gang report of April 1981, a report which represented an ideological commitment to reduce the public sector in Australia. That commitment is not being carried out because of the incapacity of this Government to see that its decisions are carried out. I refer to such other organisations as the Australian Wool Testing Authority, the proposals in relation to Telecom Australia which are now the subject of the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia and various other establishments mentioned in that inquiry which were to be sold and have not, in fact, been sold.

The terms of reference of the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories involved, in essence, inquiring into the wisdom of the decision to sell the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. As a member of the Committee, all I can say is that many days later, after very long and detailed work at an estimated cost to the taxpayer in excess of $100,000, a Senate committee of four senators reached a conclusion about this matter. When I say a Senate committee of four senators, two senators, constituting a majority-plus the more mystical part of Senator Martyr's personality in exercising his casting vote as Chairman-decided that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory ought to be sold.

The recommendations of the Committee were no mealy-mouthed recommendations such as were made by the Fraser Government. I refer the Senate to one or two of its recommendations. Senators Martyr and Crichton-Browne, two Western Australians who lobbed into the city of Bendigo on this bizarre excursion on behalf of the Fraser Government, said that there should be no mucking about with regard to the sale of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. They stated, in effect, that it should be 'now pursued with vigour, and a particular effort made to show the work force the benefits of sale.' They added that the Government should give some extra work to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory so that it would be more attractive to private enterprise to buy. That is a part of the peculiar relationship between the Government and private enterprise. It is to be encouraged to provide orders for a factory which will become a private enterprise so that a better price will be obtained when it is sold. That is the theory as expounded by the two honourable senators concerned. They then considered that sections of the factory could be sold if the Government was unable to sell the lot. Paragraph V of the Committee's recommendations states in essence that if all else fails the factory should be wound down with an official closure date to be fixed by the Government , to allow time to conclude existing commitments. They went on to say that in the event of winding down the factory the slaves should be sent to Maribyrnong and various other places where, presumably, they would be provided with work by this benevolent Government which does not provide work for many others in Australia.

That was the conclusion of the majority of the Senate Committee on this matter. It cost the taxpayers $100,000 to reach that conclusion in terms of the work of the Committee alone-work which started in September 1981 and concluded, in essence, with the publication of the Government's response to the Senate Committee's report. The recommendations of the two senators were full blooded indeed. There was no mincing of words on their part. But look what has happened. The Chairman of the Committee was truly named Martyr, because if ever a senator was martyred by the Fraser Government in pursuit of its ideological rubbish, it was that unhappy Chairman-a Western Australian senator who, with his Western Australian colleague, was sent to the provincial city of Bendigo to do this bit of ideological hatchetry on behalf of the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A pair of hit men.

—As Senator Mulvihill said, a pair of hit men who knew when they left Bendigo that they would not be going back because they recognised the consequences of what they were saying on the city and people of Bendigo. Somebody else who recognised the consequences very slowly was Mr Bourchier, the ever-silent member for Bendigo in the other place. Suddenly he recognised there were consequences for him. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) began to recognise that there were consequences for him also in what the Government had had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the performance of the Liberal Party, the so-called 'economic managers' of this country during the last few years. Let us look at this issue as a symbol of its performance. For 30 years the factory has been operating under Liberal-National Country Party governments. It has been operating at a loss to the taxpayer. In any one of those 30 years a decision could have been made to sell the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and exactly the same conditions would have obtained as obtained when this Government made the decision in April 1981.

But what was the attitude of the Fraser Government to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory five weeks prior to the 1980 election? Mr Bourchier, the member for Bendigo, presumably speaking on behalf of the Government, announced in Bendigo that if the Fraser Government were re-elected in 1980 it would spend $9m in upgrading the factory. That is what was said a month before the 1980 election. In April 1981, three months after that election the Government announced a decision not to spend $9m on it but to sell it. It is exactly the same performance as occurred following the 1977 tax cuts. It is exactly the same performance as took place with regard to tax indexation. As Professor Russell Mathews said, on three occasions it was promised before an election and abandoned after an election. The Bendigo Ordnance Factory was treated in the same manner. Before the last election it was to be upgraded, but three months later it was to be sold. These two courageous senators at least stuck with the decision of the captain on this issue and were prepared to go down with the ship . It was only when Mr Bourchier started to go down with the ship as well that the yelling really started. Earlier this year the Prime Minister went up to Bendigo and started to back away from his decision. That is recorded in the statement of the Minister for Defence Support, Mr Viner, who said that perhaps it was not such a good idea after all and that they did not really want to close the factory but in any event it was still possibly up for sale. It was a backing away comment made by the Prime Minister.

Having decided in April 1981 that the factory was for the chop and ought to be sold because it could be best run by private enterprise, in the current Budget of August 1982 the Government said: 'Now we will spend $1m on it'. I wonder what changed in that time. Look at the sequence of events. Prior to the 1980 election $9m was to be spent on the factory and three months later there was a decision to sell it. There was then an inquiry and a decision not to sell it but to spend $1m on it. No wonder people are suspicious about an early election. It is no wonder that the people of Bendigo do not believe for a moment that this factory will survive if the Fraser Government is ever re-elected. They do not believe it for a moment because they have been played for suckers by this Government for too long over this issue. The Fraser Government has no credibility left in that city. Mr Bourchier can break his elected silence of seven years in Parliament, during which he hardly said a word to crow about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, but it will do him not a bit of good.

In conclusion, the Senate inquiry into the sale of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory was not in vain. For the first time, I, as an Opposition senator participating in an inquiry, prevailed, with Senator Siddons, as a dissenting member of the Committee and the Government accepted our advice rather than the advice of the two unhappy characters over there, Senator Martyr and Senator Crichton-Browne, who no doubt will think twice before they again volunteer as shock troops for the ideological commitments of Malcolm Fraser. I have noticed in the last few years that it is not a course that commends itself to Senator Withers, and I guess it does not commend itself any more to Senator Martyr and Senator Crichton -Browne.

The Senate Select Committee did establish a few things. The first is that the defence forces procurement process in this country is incompetent. The report contains a chart of how defence equipment is procured. It looks like the inside of a transistor. It shows all the various committees through which the process goes. There was every indication in the evidence given to the Committee that the system is incompetent. Secondly, the Committee clearly established that this Government takes absolutely no notice of House of Representatives committees relating to foreign affairs and defence which on a number of occasions have recommended an upgrading of the defence procurement process as well as a whole series of new guidelines for the defence procurement process. This Government has taken no notice of the recommendations of the House of Representatives member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in relation to these matters.

The third thing that the Senate Committee established was that the word ' decentralisation', often used by this Government, particularly National Country Party members of the coalition, is absolutely meaningless in any sort of philosophical terms to a government led by Malcolm Fraser in which the National Country Party is in coalition. I can understand it in relation to areas like education where the National Country Party has a vested interest in keeping people in the country ignorant, otherwise they would vote Labor or Liberal, but I do not understand it in relation to a factory like the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. In these terms the Government's lip service to such an expression is absolutely meaningless.

Fourthly, the Committee showed that for 30 years governments had been labouring under a delusion about whether this factory could perform so-called commercial work-that is, work for private enterprise-in addition to defence work. Yet Mr Viner, after all these 30 years, went into the House of Representatives the other day and made a statement saying how delighted he was to see that the Victorian Government would give work to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. For 30 years governments and public servants have been hiding behind a totally false interpretation of the decision of the High Court of Australia in the so-called clothing trades case. That is an extraordinary thing. At least it is some justification for Senate committees that that was found out by this Senate Committee and that charade cannot go on any longer.

The final thing which the Senate Committee was able to establish was that the so-called razor gang was totally incompetent in the way in which it went about its business. If it had properly considered any of the information which must have been available to it before it could have made such a decision then it could not have arrived at the conclusion which it did because the fact of the matter is that to sell the Bendigo Ordnance Factory to private enterprise and keep it going would cost the Australian taxpayer just as much money as it would to keep it under its present management. So the Senate committee of inquiry has been worth while. I congratulate the Chairman and Senator Crichton-Browne on the experience which they have gained as members of the Committee. I do not think we will see them volunteering much again.

It has focussed attention on both factories and I believe everybody now has a much better idea of their worth to the community. Heavy engineering should be looked on as an important national asset. It should be an asset of which we are proud. I believe that that is now much more the Government's attitude. I have read the Government's report with some interest. There are just one or two things that I believe should be highlighted, some lessons that, undoubtedly, we have learned. The first is that although $1m is to be spent at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory in the next 12 months, this represents no special allocation. This money is to be spent on replacing certain vital pieces of equipment that have been in the system for quite some time. Replacement was needed at least two years ago. Therefore, so far there has been no commitment by the Government to modernise substantially the plant at Bendigo. All members of the Committee pointed out that much of that plant, whilst essential, was tending to become obsolescent.

The other important lesson that the Committee has drawn to the attention of the Government-I do hope the Government will take note of it-is the need to work sufficient man hours in the factory at Bendigo to make it economically viable. This year 310,000 man hours are budgeted for, only 6 per cent more than the number of man hours worked last year. Until the factory reaches at least 340,000 man hours a year it cannot even approach viability. This is an urgent task. From there on, there should be a long term plan for the man-hours worked to increase by at least 60,000 per year.

There is almost unlimited scope for that to happen. The Government is already well advanced in planning to build and assemble most of the British Hamel 105- millimetre howitzer at Bendigo. This is very good news because the burning lesson that we as a nation have already learnt from the catastrophe of placing the order for the 155-millimetre howitzer to be built in the United States of America is very real. The 155-millimetre howitzer was urgently needed within one year of the placing of the order in the United States. That time is now. The Army urgently needs that piece of equipment. On the spot investigation only a few weeks ago indicated that it will be at least three years before that urgent piece of equipment will be available to the Australian Army.

That is the critical lesson to be learnt. Relying on off-shore contractors to produce for us vital pieces of equipment is safe only when there is no urgency. As soon as there is a world emergency or any likelihood of war in any part of the world, the availability of these sorts of vital pieces of defence equipment tends to disappear. We must have the capability in our own country to produce at least the basics of what is required for our fighting forces. Surely field artillery is one of the basics.

There is a lot of scope for additional man-hours to be worked in the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. In negotiating contracts over the years, the Government has great scope to use off-shore facilitation procedures, commonly known as the memorandum of understanding and Australian industry participation. Under both of these concepts we have available considerable scope for negotiating additional defence work in Australia. It was very noticeable to members of the Committee that sufficient attention had not been paid by the Government to insisting upon our rights in regard to parts of contracts being undertaken in Australia.

Finally, I draw attention to the most significant lesson of all. Senator Button alluded to it. Here again, I should like to commend Mr Ian Viner, the Minister for Defence Support, who recently visited Bendigo and sought the opinions of management, the unions and the professional staff as to how best to reorganise the management of the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo. I understand that he is very co-operative in regard to a basic reorganisatoin and the principle of decentralisation of management. Greater authority to the chief executive of the factories has been at least verbally supported by the Government. There is some talk of going back to an organisational structure that we had 40 years ago-it worked very well-under which all the defence factories were essentially under the control of the Defence Department. An ordnance officer could make decisions quickly, as opposed to the present arrangements whereby the factories report to a bureaucracy here in Canberra, which is so remote and so removed from what is going on in the various areas around Australia as to be very ineffective as a final point of authority.

In summary, although the Committee has taken exactly 12 months to produce its final report, I believe the exercise has been very worth while. We now have a much better appreciation of the great asset we have in our Government defence factories. There is every indication that the Government will concentrate on making them efficient, changing the management structure and generally gearing these assets up into something of which the nation can be proud.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the Senate I table volume 1 of interim report No. 4 of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Senate, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of volume 1 of interim report No. 4 of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union presented by the Attorney-General this day.
Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The volume I have tabled is part of a series of interim reports the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has provided since it was established by the Commonwealth and Victorian governments in September 1980. The first two reports dealt with unfolding investigations and, on the advice of the Royal Commissioner, Mr F. X. Costigan, Q.C., they were not tabled. The third interim report, which dealt largely with fraudulent taxation schemes, was tabled earlier this year. The Government recently received the Commission's fourth interim report, in three volumes. Mr Costigan recommended against tabling the second and third volumes, but saw no objection in regard to volume 1 and envisaged that it would be made public.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has given very close consideration to the question of the tabling of volume 1. That volume includes findings and observations that make damaging allegations in relation to a number of individuals. Findings and conclusions of a royal commission are matters that need to be taken seriously, though they are not, of course, findings of guilt whether they relate to criminal offences or to matters of discipline. For criminal charges, the guilt or innocence of a person is determined by the courts; for disciplinary charges, Acts of parliament provide for decisions by appropriate tribunals. Notwithstanding these considerations, the Government has concluded that there is an overriding public interest in the maters canvassed that calls for tabling of all but two paragraphs of that volume. Two paragraphs have been excluded having regard to their contents and to the fact the Commissioner is to make further inquiries into the matter discussed in them.
Matters Relating to the Union, its Members and Others

The report gives substance to the grave concerns that led the Government to set up the Royal Commission. Volume 1 deals with the Commission's knowledge and findings on some aspects of the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, its members and persons associated with them. It describes a history of violence, and the ruthless means by which members of the union have arrogated to themselves a position outside the law. It tells of the union's ability to provide individuals with a new name and a new identity, and some of the uses that are made of these.

The Royal Commission has developed a practice of referring to appropriate law enforcement agencies particular criminal activities as they are identified. Many of the activities described in the report are of direct concern to Victoria and its police. The Victorian Government has a copy of the report except for paragraphs 1.13 and 1.14 and chapter 3 which appear only in the report to the Governor-General.

The Royal Commission has pointed in another volume to the need for a special group to prepare and conduct the prosecutions necessary to suppress the criminal activity uncovered by its continuing investigations. The Government stands ready to set up such a group. I will be considering this matter urgently in consultation with Mr Costigan, who is overseas at the moment, and the Victorian Government.
Action to Progress Taxation Prosecutions

Attention is also being given as a matter of priority to the prosecution of offences associated with 'bottom of the harbour' tax evasion schemes which are referred to in volume 1. In June this year the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and I took steps to obtain advice from the Solicitor-General in regard to the availability of prosecution action in the particular case dealt with in chapter 3 of volume 1 . The Solicitor-General, in an opinion delivered later in the same month, advised that certain remedies were open. Advice was also sought from senior counsel in June on possible criminal proceedings in relation to a major promoter in Sydney. A final opinion is expected shortly. On the particular case referred to in chapter 3 of the report, the Crown Solicitor sent an officer from his central office in Canberra to Perth to work in association with the Australian Taxation Office to complete a brief to advise on evidence and to draw charges as appropriate. That brief has now been delivered to senior counsel.

More generally it has been decided to appoint a special prosecutor to concentrate special effort on action with a view to prosecution of persons who were directly involved in the promotion and execution of bottom of the harbour schemes. The special prosecutor will be assisted by a task force of lawyers, taxation officers and police. There will be liaison with the Royal Commission. Additional staff and resources will be provided as needed. We will be seeking the fullest co-operation from State authorities where they may be involved. The Victorian Government has already proposed a joint effort and I will be discussing this matter with it.

Decisions on prosecutions or other proceedings will, of course, be made on the evidence available and on the law applicable. But I am firmly of the view that those who were most directly involved in the promotion and execution of blatantly fraudulent tax evasion schemes should be dealt with when their conduct can be shown to have been in breach of the criminal law. Where appropriate, civil action for recovery of moneys will be pursued as well.
National Crimes Commission and the Future of the Royal Commission

The Royal Commission's fourth interim report underlines the need which the Government has seen for some time for the establishment of a National Crimes Commission. Mr Costigan himself has recommended action along these lines. The Commonwealth envisages a National Crimes Commission as a standing body, established by legislation, with special powers to investigate and initiate action against serious criminal activity. Such a body would supplement existing law enforcement efforts in areas of need. In particular, a Crimes Commission could be directed to organised crime; white collar crime; and corruption of officials and official bodies.

The primary objective of such a Commission would be to bring about prosecutions in appropriate cases. The Commission would be involved in such prosecutions rather than recommending prosecutions and leaving action on them to others. It would not produce reports naming individuals as suspected of committing criminal offences.

The Commonwealth is seeking the co-operation of the States. The matter was discussed at the Police Ministers Conference last week and will be discussed further at the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General later this week. The Royal Commission's report is relevant to the deliberations of those meetings.

Mr Costigan refers in the volume that has been tabled to other areas, mentioned in the confidential volumes, that are of major significance and concern to Government and the community. He says his Commission will be unable to complete its investigations by its present report date of 31 December 1982 and states that continued investigation must take place whether by his Commission or some other body. The Government would see the proposed National Crimes Commission as an appropriate body in due course to carry on the work of the Royal Commission. In the meantime, the Government will consult with the Victorian Government on the question of extending Mr Costigan's commission.
Findings Affecting the Crown Solicitor's Office

Chapter 3 of volume 1 focuses on an episode of particular concern to the Government. The episode relates to the performance of the Crown Solicitor's Division of my Department and in particular of the office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth. The report recounts the handling by the Crown Solicitor's office of a case of an alleged fraudulent tax evasion scheme referred to it in 1974 by the Australian Taxation Office in Perth following an investigation by that office. The scheme, of the kind commonly referred to as a bottom-of-the- harbour scheme, involved the stripping of company assets so as to cheat the revenue of taxes. The report states that, after counsel's opinion was obtained, the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office was requested in August 1975 to commence a prosecution. Mr Costigan reports a history of events and circumstances in the handling of the matter by the Crown Solicitor's office, and of dealings between that office and the Taxation Office. The history reveals inaction and negligence on the part of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth. The problems described are said to go further than the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth, and to bear on the control and supervision of the Perth office by the Crown Solicitor's central office in Canberra. The matter concluded with advice from the Crown Solicitor's central office that the evidence was insufficient to establish a criminal conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth.

I should not be taken as accepting without reservation all the conclusions and views expressed by the Commissioner in relation to individual persons. I do not accept the views expressed by the Commissioner in paragraph 3.89 of the report to the effect that a new law was not needed. But the views expressed require action.
Remedial Action in Regard to the Crown Solicitor's Office

The standing of the Crown Solicitor's office, and the integrity and competence of some of its officers, are brought into question by these matters. The proper course is to deal with the problem quickly and effectively. A number of officers referred to in the report have retired since the time of their involvement. There is no suggestion that any committed a criminal offence. The Commission has been critical of some officers who remain on staff. It has expressed conclusions of a very serious character in relation to two officers. One of these officers was directly involved in the conduct of the particular case referred to by the Commission. Another was not officially involved in it but in the course of its investigation the Commission found some association between this officer and a number of companies which seem to have been involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Other conduct in which this officer was found to be involved also gives cause for concern.

As a first step, the divisional manager of the Crown Solicitor's Division was sent to Perth to undertake inquiries there and to examine work in the office that was allotted to those officers. The two officers have been suspended from duty pending decisions whether or not to charge either or both of them with disciplinary offences under the Public Service Act. Appropriate action under that Act is in process.

On the wider questions of organisation, management and control of the Crown Solicitor's Division, the former Crown Solicitor initiated an internal management review in 1978 which culminated in the establishment of a Joint Management Review of the Crown Solicitor's Division in 1979. That review was carried out from November 1979 to June 1980. That review, by a team consisting of a private management consultant, a representative of the Public Service Board and a Crown Solicitor's officer, recommended major changes in the management structure. Its recommendations were readily accepted by my Department. Considerable progress has been made in implementation. One of the major recommendations of the Joint Management Review was for the establishment of a Management and Co-ordination Branch of the Crown Solicitor's Division headed by a First Assistant Crown Solicitor having a local designation of Divisional Manager. A major function of this Branch is to develop and improve Deputy Crown Solicitor's offices and to co-ordinate, guide and oversight the work of those offices. The three top positions in the branch are filled and working. Other appointments are in train.

There remains however, a question as to the adequacy of the staff resources of the Crown Solicitor's Division. The Government has asked the Public Service Board to report to it as a matter of urgency on the adequacy of the staffing and resources of the Crown Solicitor's office. In view of the Royal Commission's findings, however, the Government sees a need for a more particular external examination of the Perth office and its relationship to the Crown Solicitor's central office in Canberra and with the Australian Taxation Office and other client bodies in Perth. I am arranging for such an exsmaination to be carried out by the President of the Law Council of Australia or by a suitably qualified person nominated by the President. In brief, the terms of reference of the inquiry will be as follows:
To review the operation of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office, Perth generally , but with particular regard to- (a) the professional performance of the office;
(b) the adequacy of the management and the effectiveness of work control systems;
(c) the adequacy of numbers of professional and support staff to ensure the timely performance of work at an appropriate level of quality;
(d) the effectiveness of the organisation of the office for the provision of legal services for the Commonwealth Government;
(e) the effectiveness of supervision of the office by the Crown Solicitor's central office; and
(f) the effectiveness of procedures in client Departments in relation to matters referred to the office.
Recommendations for Changes in Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Royal Commissions Act

Mr Costigan has recommended a number of changes in the secrecy provisions of sectionb 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to allow in particular for more access to, and use of , Taxation Office information in law enforcement. These recommendations are for changes additional to the amendments to the secrecy provisions made earlier this year. The Government will give early and careful consideration to these recommendations. The Government will also examnine carefully the Royal Commission's recommendations for amendments to the Royal Commissions Act to provide additional powers in regard to search warrants and compulsion of witnesses. I move:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the bland character of the statement by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and its manner of presentation tended as always to conceal it, the Costigan Report-Interim Report No. 4 of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union- contains a mass of stunning revelations and findings not only, as might have been expected, about the criminal activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union on and off the waterfront, not only about the professional ethics, credit and credibility of Mr Frank Galbally, the lawyer who has acted for that union over the years in a variety of diverse capacities, but above all else, about the incompetence and corruption that is rife within the Public Service over which this Government presides and for which this Government is responsible . SPEECH.PARA: The focus of the report, in the first instance in chapter 3, the 80-page chapter which is the nub and essence of this particular document, is upon the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth, within the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department. That focus arises from the fact that it was in Perth, as a result of some effective investigation in the first instance by an investigative officer of the Australian Taxation Office, that the matter of a prosecution of a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme was first referred to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office for prosecution. Certainly by 1976, if not earlier, the possibility and indeed the necessity of launching such a prosecution and the certainty of its standing up was a matter of satisfaction to the Australian Federal Police. But it was in Perth and in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office of the Attorney-General's Department in Perth that that particular, crucial test-case prosecution ground to a halt. It was as a result of an extraordinary sequence of events which are retailed in this report that in fact no prosecutions were ever launched against any participant in a bottom-of- the-harbour scheme anywhere, with consequences of which we are well aware and which Mr Costigan documents.

What this report exposes in the result in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth is an unbelievably festering mess, involving not only extraordinary professional incompetence and extraordinary professional negligence, but also corruption in the form of active participation by a senior member of that Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office and his wife in a whole series of his own bottom-of-the -harbour companies. It has been said there were as many as 200. The report itself states that Mr Costigan is unable to judge just how many were involved but within the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office itself was a flourishing mini-tax evasion-avoidance industry going on. To make matters complete, also within the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office one particular gentleman-the same gentleman who was actively involved in the tax avoidance exercise-had a nice little call-girl prostitution racket being run partly out of the DCS Office itself. This is the matter which the Attorney-General's statement rather coyly describes as 'other conduct giving rise for concern'.

While the rot started in the DCS Office in Perth it is clear that the rot did not stop there. The Costigan report makes it very clear that responsibility for the extraordinary sequence of events which resulted in the lamentable non- prosceution, as Mr Costigan says, of these cases is shared by senior levels of the DCS Office in Perth-not just junior echelons-and by the Central Crown Solicitor's Office, extending all the way up to the Crown Solicitor himself. The report also makes it evident, although Mr Costigan's sympathies are rather more with the Australian Taxation Office than with the Crown Solicitor's Division, that a degree of responsibility is also shared by senior officers within the Australian Taxation Office who, although they were clearly unhappy with the quality of the responses they were getting from DCS, allowed themselves to be shoved about from pillar to post by what was obviously an unbelievably implausible dilatoriness on the part of the officers within the Attorney-General 's Department. Nor does the rot stop there. By extension it is clear that the rot extends all the way up to the top of the political tree itself, to the Ministers in this Government and especially the Attorney-General and the Treasurer (Mr Howard), both of whom have been claiming to have been acting so diligently to counter tax avoidance and evasion in its most horrendous forms. I should add that the Commissioner, Mr Costigan, does find some extenuation, so far as the Ministers are respectively concerned, in the secrecy provisions of the tax Act-section 16-which he says makes and made the task of ministerial supervision of the officers in question somewhat difficult.

I make it clear-I do so on behalf of my party and I think it will be very clear to the community at large-that I do not accept that that supervision was beyond the resources, beyond the capacity or beyond the power of either of the Ministers concerned. The Costigan report makes a number of things very clear.
