The second thing that is made very clear in the report, by some very solid legal analysis spread over many pages, is that there is and always has been a solid legal foundation for the criminal prosecution of those involved in bottom- of-the-harbour schemes, whether as vendors, as purchasers or as promoters of the schemes in question. There are and always have been remedies available under the Crimes Act, the Companies Act, under the common law and also under the civil law of misfeasance.

The third thing that Mr Costigan makes clear is that there has always been a solid factual foundation on which a test case-in particular the test case in Perth around which this report focuses-could have been prosecuted. The notion, which was assiduously promoted by the officers in question who had charge of this matter in the Perth office, that what was needed was something almost like a confession on the part of the participants in order to establish the necessary intention to defraud is exploded by Mr Costigan and demonstrated to be the nonsense that it is. All that is necessary is that the fraudulent intention be able to be inferred from overt acts-and there were plenty of overt acts which were amply documented and which were always available not only to the Taxation Office but also to the DCS, which was charged with the task of implementing a prosecution.

The fourth thing that Mr Costigan makes admirably clear in his report is that the bureaucracy knew these things, knew about the legal and the factual foundation in the first instance no later than 1974-and certainly by late 1975- that there was not just one but two Queen's Counsel's opinions from Mr Brinsden, QC, in Perth by then. This was then confirmed by the subsequent police investigation which concluded-it was rather long-winded but very thorough-in 1976.

The fifth thing that Mr Costigan makes clear is that there is no foundation in law or in any emerging new further facts for the change of heart which occurred within the bureaucracy, resulting in the prosecution of the Perth test case, and with that the prosecution of everything else that was in issue, being abandoned in April 1979 on the say so of the Central Crown Solicitor's Office. The reason for it being abandoned owed nothing to any re-evaluation of a serious kind of the law or to any change in the facts available; it resulted from the saga of incompetence, indolence, negligence and possibly worse which occurred, and is documented in enormous detail in the Costigan report, within the DCS Office in Perth and which was not subject to any challenge, second guessing, or proper supervision by higher officers within the Crown Solicitor's Division in Perth, Canberra, or anywhere else.

The final thing that Mr Costigan makes clear is that there is no basis on which it should be assumed that the 1980 Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was ever necessary, at least to correct the deficiencies in the present law as it related to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It may have been helpful in dealing with the sales tax frauds that became apparent some time earlier-Mr Costigan acknowledges that-but there was no reason why effective action could not and should not have been taken a lot earlier than that.

So we have a situation that, under the noses of the Treasurer, the Attorney- General and others whom I will mention, an absolutely extraordinary situation occurred. Not only was there a flourishing small-beer prostitution racket within the DCS Office, not only a mini tax avoidance industry within the Perth DCS Office but also a combination of corruption, negligence and incompetence which was rife within that office and clearly higher up the tree too resulting in a situation where a prosecution which could have been launched and turned the whole bottom-of-the-harbour industry on its head as early as 1976 did in fact collapse in a heap. What happened is that the nation incurred, as a result, at least hundreds and possibly thousands of millions of dollars worth of lost revenue which has had obvious effects elsewhere in the tax system.

I say it occurred under the noses of various people and I make that point as clearly as I possibly can. It occurred in the first place under the nose of the Treasurer, Mr Howard, who has been claiming, of course, for the last five or six years that he has been taking every possible legislative and administrative step to cope with tax avoidance and tax evasion in every one of its manifestations. But certainly the Australian Taxation Office knew what was going on, knew the way in which this matter-which was crucial to the whole administrative attempt to counter what was going on-could and should have been dealt with. Certainly the Australian Taxation Office could have communicated through the Commissioner to Mr Howard the substance, if not the details, of the particular prosecution strategy. Certainly, what was going wrong and what was causing the delay should have been communicated to Mr Howard, and I do not doubt that it was communicated .

We have had from Mr Howard something less than total frankness in his own explanation of the course of events and the failure of the prosecution in question to be launched on the McCabe-Lafranchi report of 27 June which indicated in a very sketchy kind of a way the sequence of events, as it was known, according to Mr Howard, to him, the Treasury and the Taxation Office during the relevant period. While Mr Howard acknowledges that as early as 1974 and 1975 there were opinions which made it clear that prosecutions could have been launched, he simply says, at a passage in his statement, that as a result of further discussions which took place over the period 1976-79 it became clear that there was no foundation on which the prosecutions could successfully have been launched. Well, Mr Costigan has flushed Mr Howard out and shown that particular Press statement and the account in it for the fudging that it in fact represents. Whether that fudging was deliberate on the Treasurer's part or whether it owes more to the incompetence of his own officials rather than to any malice or dishonesty is something that will be for this Parliament and the community to judge. But let there be no mistake about it; Mr Howard's statement was less than full, less than frank, and certainly gave a less than adequate account of the Treasurer's own role in this whole unhappy unfair.

So far as the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, is concerned, he, of course, is the chief law officer in this country, responsible ultimately for the prosecutions that are launched under the Federal criminal law, and committed, supposedly, as he is in that capacity, to waging the Government's war on tax avoidance. He is the Minister responsible for everything that happens within his Department. It may also be noted that the Minister happens to live in Perth and might perhaps as a result be expected to know a little bit more than perhaps some others about the personnel involved in that enterprise. Whether again it is a result of something worse than negligence on the Minister's part must be a matter for this Parliament and for the nation to judge. But negligence it undoubtedly was, negligence which is totally incompatible with the doctrine of ministerial responsibility which is assumed to exist, which is claimed to exist, in any Westminster system of Government. The Attorney stands condemned, I believe, for his role in allowing this extraordinary sequence of events to occur . Someone else stands condemned and who I do think deserves to be mentioned, although it is not with any great pleasure that I do this, is Mr Alan Neaves, the present Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, who was Crown Solicitor from February 1975 until July 1979 and a man of whom Senator Durack and this Government thought so highly that he was subsequently elevated to the position of Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department. It is clear from the Cositigan report that Mr Neaves knew, certainly, of everything that had been going wrong in relation to this prosecution and the abominable saga of mismanagement within the Perth DCS at least as early as March 1978. I would not wish it to be thought that Mr Neaves or indeed, any one of a number of others in a large cast of characters comes off scott free form the Costigan report. I believe there is an element of culpability at that level, that very senior level , within the Department. I make the point and I make the reference to indicate that we are not talking about some minor order characters in the play being incompetent, being negligent or being corrupt. We are talking about that incompetence and that negligence, at least, leading up to the highest levels of the Department, with implications that should be obvious so far as the responsibility of the Minister himself is concerned.

The question then becomes this: What action does the Government propose to take ? What has it said it is going to do in response to the Costigan report? The Attorney's statement today gives no confidence, or should not give anyone any confidence, that the Government has learned any lesson from this report, no confidence that it will mend its ways, no confidence that it will in the future be any more effective against the tax avoidance and tax evasion industries than it has been in the past. The first things that we are told is going to happen is the suspension of two officers in Perth. My understanding is that those two officers are Mr O'Sullivan, Jnr, and Mr Bercove, both of whom come in for a quite explicit caning, justifiably so, in the Costigan report. Indeed, there could be hardly anything other than a suspension as the appropriate course of action in response to them. They would be very lucky indeed, I would believe, on the evidence in this report if they escape with merely disciplinary action under the Public Service Act which is apparently what is being presently contemplated by the Attorney-General. My query is whether the buck should stop there with those two relatively junior officers, the only two officers against whom it is proposed or it is stated that explicit action will occur.

There are a number of other figures named in that report. I have mentioned one of them; there are several others. Although some have since retired it seems, at least on my initial reading-I have not had very long to tackle what is a very lengthy report-that the official level of responsibility for the course of events in Perth ought not to be regarded as stopping with the two officers who have in fact been suspended and that responsibility ought to extend at a bureaucratic level all the way up the Attorney-General's Department.

The second thing that we are told is happening is that here is to be a full scale management study or exercise introduced in relation to the Crown Solicitor 's Office generally and more particularly the Perth office. Well, that is of course wholly desirable, lamentably belated as it may be. I simply indicate that we can hardly be expected as a parliament, as a nation, to have very much confidence in the outcome of that particular management inquiry unless and until there is a fundamental change of personnel at a very significant number of levels within that particular division of that particular department and a complete clean-out of the mess that is so starkly revealed by the Costigan report.

The third thing we are told is going to happen is the setting in train immediately of particular prosecutions on the matters which did collapse, again in Mr Costigan's words, so lamentably as the result of the neglect and incompetence and possibly worse of the Attorney-General's Department. Immediate action, we are told, is being taken through all available avenues, including the appointment of a special prosecutor. I simply comment in respect of that and in the light of past experience, that I will believe it, my party will believe it and the community will believe it when it sees that action is in fact taking effect. Whether that action does take an effective course, not only in relation to those particular matters but also to the many others which obviously are crying out now for criminal prosecution, will depend very much on how far- reaching is the Government's action with respect to the next thing it says it is going to do and that is establish a task force of lawyers, tax officers and police to engage, in the fullest co-operation in the first instance with the Victorian Government and then presumably others, in the task of actually prosecuting to fruition under the criminal law, and where necessary the civil law as well, those who so manifestly deserve that particular attention.

I can reveal that so far at least that co-operation does not seem to have been particularly forthcoming from the Commonwealth level. It is my understanding that over 10 days ago, on 13 August, the Victorian Premier and Attorney-General wrote to Senator Durack proposing the immediate establishment of a joint prosecutorial force to proceed immediately with prosecutions in those areas where the evidence was already on the books. I understand it was said in that letter that the Victorians had a team ready and willing to go consisting of the Crown Solicitor, the Chief Crown Counsel and a special prosecutor with appropriate back-up staff. Not only has no written reply been received to that letter sent more than 10 days ago; but also it is my further understanding that orally Senator Durack has in fact advised the Victorian Government that he is not interested in that particular proposal. He does not want it to proceed in that form but, at best, he will have a think about it. The Attorney-General has been having a think about the procedures by which prosecution should be launched . He and his Department have been having a think about it for something like eight years now-since 1974. The have failed lamentably to deliver the goods and, in the process, this nation and the taxpayers of this nation have suffered enormously.

I ask him to have a think again, a very specific think, about just what kind of a prosecution policy he and his Government are now going to set in train. We are facing exactly the same lethargy, exactly the same indolence and exactly the same inaction in the face of gravity and in the face of emergencies that have characterised this particular Ministry and this particular Minister, I fear, from the outset. Mr Connolly, the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts referred, a few months ago, to the 'glacial' pace at which the Attorney -General's Department moved in giving opinions and advice in response to requests from other departments. I have referred in this place and I refer again to the pathological lethargy of this particular deparment and this particular Minister when it comes not just to talking about something but to doing something.

The final avow, of course, in the Government's quiver is the establishment-the proposal gets tighter and tighter with each successive public utterance of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or his Cabinet members-of a permanent National Crimes Commission. This, it appears, is to be the white horse that Mr Fraser and the law enforcers, or those of them who are left in the Government's Ministry, are now to ride home. This is to be the answer to the problem of organised crime, tax evasion, official corruption and everything else that the present court system has failed so far effectively to deliver upon. But what kind of a beast will be constituted by his crimes commission remains still, after this statement today, impossibly unclear.

The Australian Labor Party has spelt out on a number of recent occasions its attitude to the crimes commission concept. I do it again briefly here today. It is not opposed in any way, root and branch, to the concept of some alternative form of dealing with intractable areas of crime where the existing legal system has demonstrably proved ineffective and where it is arguable that a more inquisitorial approach, at least at the investigative stage, will bear more effective fruit in the community's interest. But the Australian Labor Party has said that it will not jump on to the band wagon and buy the whole package, root and branch, until and unless it is satisfied about a number of very important considerations. The Australian Labor Party is worried, in the first place, about the accountability of any such organisation, particularly one set up on a joint Federal-State basis. As I said the other day and as Senator Peter Rae echoed, organisations which are accountable to everyone in the Federal system can, in practice, end up as accountable to no one. If the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence is to be the model, as some Ministers in other States have suggested, on which the crimes commission is to be established that is potentially a very worrying consideration indeed. Secondly, the Australian Labor Party is worried about the safeguards that will be associated with the exercise of powers by any such national crimes commission. All sorts of dangers are involved in inquisitorial bodies exercising unbridled investigative and reporting powers. There are all sorts of situations in which malicious hearsay gossip can in fact be elevated, through its reporting in the media, to the status of fact when, of course, it will not survive any such scrutiny by reference to ordinary court standards. We need to be satisfied about what is proposed and there is nothing in Senator Durack's statement which does so satisfy us.

Above all-this is the point which brings us back to the nub of the report presented today-the Labor Party is worried about what any such national crimes commission will actually do with its findings. The Attorney said in his statement that it is not just going to name people for others to prosecute, but about that the concept has changed. We are going to have an organisation which itself is going to 'bring about' prosecution. We are confronted with the possibility that we will have a body, if this is established in the way that the Government seems to want it established, that is armed with the power to investigate, through compulsive oral investigation of witnesses and the subpoenaing of evidence a body which is armed in a fully open-ended way with access to tax records in a way that is more far reaching than the recently amended law-that is a Costigan Royal Commission recommendation; a body which is armed with the power to issue search warrants, which is another Costigan Royal Commission recommendation in this report; a body which is armed with the power to make public any information it wants to at any time either in the course of public hearings or in the context of an actual report; and a body now, apparently, with the power itself to prosecute.

This proposed national crimes commission lacks only the power to gaol, to have all the elements of prosecution, judging and gaoling vested in the one set of hands-something which has traditionally and quite properly been regarded as inappropriate. It is not clear from the Costigan report that this kind of animal is in fact needed. The Opposition certainly will take a lot more persuading that it is needed. The Costigan Royal Commission made it perfectly clear that the problem with the present law is not the non-existence of a crimes commission body to launch prosecutions itself but the failure of the existing, perfectly adequate, on the face of it, departmental machinery to play that particular role . The job could and should have been done by others.

At the end of the day, we are left with this: The nub of the indictment against this Government is that in the face of a massive criminal fraud which it must have known about since at least 1976; in the face of easy legal remedies to deal with that fraud which it must have known about from the documents within the bureaucracy in 1974, 1975 and, at the latest, by 1976; and supported as those original opinions were by a series of subsequent high level legal opinions, this Government and these Ministers-the Treasurer and the Attorney-General-failed to take action. There may be some claim of justification on their part for their failure to take action in terms of the information available to them under section 16 of the Act. As I have said, I do not believe that this Parliament ought to take that particular explanation seriously. They must give a more plausible explanation of their action and inaction, their sins of both omission and commission. This Parliament and the nation, will not be satisfied until the relevant Ministers, the Attorney and the Treasurer stand up and do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report that we are considering today begins its introduction at page 2 with the rather interesting statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Information obtained during these confidential hearings and from these documents-
Documents that it refers to as coming in by the semi-trailer load from Sydney and by the container load from another source which I prefer not to disclose publicly--
is both revealing and disturbing.

Without question I would say, as Senator Evans has already pointed out, the most disturbing information stems from the behaviour, the actions and the lack of actions of a number of members of the Crown Solicitor's Office, particularly in Perth. Mr Costigan's comments regarding these officers and his assessment of the results of their actions and the cost to the community are damaging indeed. The Royal Commissioner turned his attention in the first part of his fourth interim report to what have recently come to be called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. They are defined at page 26 of the report in terms used by a Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in 1977. I will not bother to outline those since they are considerably detailed and honourable senators can read them at their leisure. Interestingly, Mr Costigan takes some pains to separate, a little later in the report, the operation and intention of these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes from the Slutzkin-type scheme-a scheme which was, shall we say, exonerated by a High Court decision. At page 89, the Commissioner makes the point:

The statistics provided to me by the Taxation Office concern two types of application of the schemes described in this report. The first concerns companies which have accumulated profits, but on which they have paid company tax. The purpose of the application of the scheme is to avoid the payment of tax on the distribution of these profits to the shareholders. It was this type of operation that the decision in Slutzkin was concerned. It is not the type of case with which I am concerned in this report.
Paragraph 3.120 states:

The second type of case is of a very different order . . . the Taxation Office describes it as a 'pre-tax profit strip'. In these cases the object is to avoid payment of the company tax properly levied upon the company by leaving only a shell of the company with no assets to pay the tax.

More interestingly, he expresses strongly the opinion that these schemes are not only illegal-that is, the second type of case to which he refers-under the present Act as amended but also were illegal before that and were permitted to exist-indeed, permitted to flourish-only because of failure to act by the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. In paragraph 3.89 at page 70 he points out:

What was worse was that the Crown Solicitor's Office permitted the inference to arise that the existing law was not adequate and that new laws were needed. Thus the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia was induced to enact new criminal laws of great breadth and scope when all that was required was the enforcement of the existing laws. To say that the new laws have been effective is not to answer this criticism. The new laws will be effective only if they are enforced. The conduct to which they are directed is conduct which was already criminal.
Mr Costigan is quite definite in his opinion regarding the end result of the behaviour of Messrs O'Sullivan, Jnr, and Bercove. He makes that quite clear at page 71 in paragraph 3.90, where he says:

The criminal proceedings would have had a salutory effect upon the promotion of the fraudulent schemes. At the very least they would probably have led to the loss of liberty of the particular promoter concerned, thus inhibiting further promotion by him. It would have served as a warning to others who later chose to adopt and promote his schemes. They probably would have deterred them.

Page 89 gives a list of most disturbing statistics which indicate just exactly how those schemes flourished because of the lack of action by the Crown Solicitor's Office. It is noted that, in 1973, 27 companies throughout Australia were identified as operating this particular scheme. By 1980, 1,412 companies had been identified in Australia as operating this kind of scheme-a proliferation which Mr Costigan makes quite clear occurred only because of lack of action, if not actual negligence, on the part of certain officers in the Crown Solicitor's Office. Given the Commissioner's comments regarding the enforceability of the earlier legislation, one is forced-or at least I am as a mere lay person-to wonder why the Government is mooting yet more legislation to enable it to prosecute promoters of and participants in what are known as bottom -of-the-harbour schemes which the Commissioner quite clearly indicates could have been prosecuted under previous legislation. My concern about this is supported by a letter from a much more learned person than I and which appeared last week in the Australian Financial Review. Mr Geoffrey Lehmann, lecturer in the Legal Studies and Taxation Department of the University of New South Wales made the point:

The assertion that ''innocent'' vendors of ''bottom of the harbour'' companies will be made liable ''retrospectively'' for someone else's tax under the Government's current proposals . . . requires comment.

He went on to say that he had published an article in the National Times in which he argued that such vendors were already liable for tax under section 260 and were not protected by Slutzkin's case, a comment which is certainly supported by Mr Costigan. To Mr Lehmann's knowledge, no published refutation of his submission has appeared. He then made the point:
The position is that there are six previous High Court decisions making such vendors liable and no decision directly applicable to them which would make them not liable.
He continued:
It is now most unlikely that the present High Court would reverse six previous decisions to benefit a group of blatant tax avoiders.

Thus, at best, new legislation would clarify a position already existing, according to Mr Costigan. It would speed up matters rather than make illegal something which was previously legal. The Attorney-General's assertion, in his statement to the contrary, appears to me at least to be a mere face-saving exercise to cover negligence on the part of some members of the Crown Solicitor' s Office in Perth. Indeed, one could almost say that the Attorney-General's defence of the need for new legislation justifies the action by Messrs O' Sullivan, Jnr, and Bercove, despite the fact that Mr Costigan found the actions of these officers both indefensible and unjustified.

There is no doubt in the minds of most Australians that if this Government is serious about ending tax evasion and is concerned about promoting justice in the tax laws in this country, it will prosecute with all vigour and under all the legislation available to it the purveyors of these schemes. To assist the Government in this, Mr Costigan recommends a number of extensive amendments to section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which I do not intend to discuss in any detail. They are listed quite clearly at the beginning of the report for those honourable senators who wish to follow it up.

It has become a tradition in Australia that income tax details are confidential , as they rightly should be in most cases. An individual is therefore free to give to the Taxation Office whatever details he or she chooses, secure in the knowledge that they will not be, because they cannot be, used against him or her other than by the Australian Taxation Office itself whenever necessary. I do not believe that, given the abuse of these secrecy provisions by the more greedy and less honest among us, most Australians would reject any attempt made by a government to see a relaxation of those provisions as outlined by Mr Costigan. When protecting sections of an Act serve only to protect the more dishonourable among us, and in so doing place an additional burden on the law abiding, there is good reason to view them with some scepticism and, one hopes, to take steps to amend them.

I cannot conclude my comments without making some reference to Mr Costigan's style. Senator Evans has already referred to what he called the coyness of one or two of the Commissioner's comments. This report is most readable. It is couched in what I consider delightfully straightforward language and is spiced with a large number of wryly witty comments and a good dash of irony, particularly in the sections relation to Messrs O'Sullivan, Jnr, Bercove and Gleedman. Indeed, the reference that Senator Evans has already made to the prostitution racket that seemed to be operating out of Mr Bercove's office would give the term 'Crown Solicitor' an entirely new meaning. As Senator Evans has already pointed out, there has been something less than total frankness on the part of some Government officials and some Government Ministers. There has been, to say the least, a lamentable lack of enthusiasm by officials and the Government to prosecute any of the 1,412 companies operating the scheme up to 1980. I suggest that the Government has much to answer for and the Commissioner, Mr Costigan, is to be commended for exposing the saga of negligence, misfeasance and arrogant disregard for the law, a disregard that was probably best summed up by Mr Bercove. In paragraph 3.59 of the report, referring to Mr Bercove, the Commissioner comments:
When it was put to him that this was intentionally dishonest, he was indifferent. In his view, 'everyone does it' and therefore it was good enough for him.

If we are going to allow that sort of thing to proliferate in the community, if the Government allows that sort of attitude to continue with the end result of defrauding taxpayers, then it has a considerable amount to answer for.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not bad for a senior public servant.

—Indeed and, I suggest, sets a very poor example to junior public servants. Therefore, it is up to the Government to act quickly and positively, to forget about saving face and to initiate whatever action is necessary to punish previous offenders and prevent any repetition of such offences in future. It could start by ensuring that the Crown Solicitor's offices in this country are staffed by people who are well qualified to deal with the cases that they are most likely to run up against.

SPEECH.PARA: Two of the most damning comments in the report are those relating to the qualifications, or lack of them, of Messrs Gleedman and O'Sullivan. On page 34 the Commissioner says of Mr Gleedman, an officer appointed to handle this particular form of tax evasion in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office:
He had no previous experience in criminal conspiracies. He claimed expertise in company law but it was plain from his evidence before me that he had little in that area either.
With regard to Mr Bercove, the Commissioner notes on page 47:

He had no experience in criminal law and none in company law. He remains in the Crown Solicitor's Office at Perth, and still has the responsibility of handling this matter. It is not a responsibility that he has pretended to discharge.

That this sort of thing should be allowed to happen is an indication of more than what Senator Evans referred to as lethargy on the part of the Government. It is, or could be construed to be, an indication of total apathy by this Government towards the massive tax evasion that is going on in the upper echelons of society. it is a Government that is more concerned with harassing pay-as-you-earn taxpayers or small business people. I suggest that the Australian community deserves better. If the present Government is not prepared to look to its laurels in this area, it is likely to find itself after the next election, if not at the bottom of a harbour, certainly on the opposition benches .

TALK.START.PARA: —It had been my understanding earlier today that there would be agreement on both sides of the chamber to move immediately that this matter be referred to a select committee of the Senate. Apparently there was no such agreement and it has been decided that the second reading debate will proceed. However, I still intend to move an amendment to that effect. The Plant Variety Rights Bill 1982 has generated interest almost in inverse ratio to its importance.
—Senator, I have just been advised that what you propose would have to be done by way of formal amendment of the motion for the second reading.
—Yes. Perhaps a subsequent Opposition speaker could move it formally. I merely wanted to give notice of my intention to so move during the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has been discussed freely for some four or five years. On many occasions the responsible Minister-in fact, it has been around for so long that two Ministers have been responsible for it-predicted that the legislation would be introduced in the next session of Parliament. Finally, last session, it did appear and was passed in the House of Representatives.

In the last Parliament I had responsibility for primary industry matters on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. I think I can say accurately that I received more letters on this subject than on all others combined. If I may borrow a cliche, it is a question that has generated much heat and little light.

The arguments put on both sides in this debate have been unconvincing. On the pro-PVR side it is stated that if plant variety rights conferred upon the producer of new cultivars the right to charge in accordance with what was akin to a patent right, more money would be devoted to plant breeding, with consequential absolute gains. Under some circumstances such an argument could conceivably be correct. It appears, however, that it is unlikely to be correct in Australia. In countries where the agricultural practice is for new seed to be purchased from specialist seed producers each year there is a large volume market and therefore the potential for the producer of new and superior varieties to harvest from the farmers who actually use those varieties a portion of the economic rent accruing to a new and superior variety. However, in Australian agriculture the practice is overwhelmingly that farmers buy seed only once. Therefore, for the producer of a new variety there is no captive market of large volume for either grain or most pasture species.

The prevailing belief among agricultural scientists is that there is a long term although very slight improvement in yield if the same grain is grown in the same locality generation after generation. So far from there being any economic reason for farmers to change seed-infection with disease and so on aside-there is, although it would be very difficult to calculate and one would need a fine point pencil to do it, an economic advantage is not changing seed until such time as a superior variety may be produced.

In some minor agricultural industries, particularly vegetables and horticulture , it is the custom for growers to purchase new seed each season, for a variety of both economic and agronomic reasons. So to some extent in the minor agricultural industries there does exist what could be regarded as a captive market for potential seed producers using PVR legislation. However the market is small in volume and therefore unlikely to provide sufficient financial rewards to indue the amount of investment in plant breeding that those who support the principles behind this legislation suggest. I should mention that for broadacre Australian farming, which includes grain growing and pasture production, even when a new variety is produced it is very easy to bulk up large quantities of seed grain or pasture from an initial very small purchase, so that if the producer of a superior variety were to recover from his sales the cost of research, the price of the very limited quantity of seed which he could expect to sell to an individual farmer would be so high that the farmer would be unlikely to make a purchase. In other words, the producers would seem to be facing a catch-22 situation.

It has been argued, and it used to be argued to me when I had the responsibility for agriculture, that superior plant material has been withheld from Australia because plant variety rights legislation does not exist. With one exception, and despite several requests to produce evidence of such material having been withheld, no proof was offered. The exception was information supplied to me by vegetable growers in the coastal areas of central Queensland, who for the sorts of reasons I mentioned earlier do not keep their own seed generation after generation, that a particular firm producing seed in the west of New South Wales was withholding a superior bean variety until such time as this legislation was passed.

There has been some informed criticism by the opponents of PVR. I will mention more of that later. Unfortunately, the informed criticism has been swamped by ill-informed criticism, the hallmark of which is a collection of fallacies wrapped up in various conspiracy theories usually produced by a species known somewhat scathingly to friends of mine associated with agriculture as Lygon Street farmers. Of course those friends reside in Melbourne; appropriate names for the same species could be devised for other cities. These people are confused in many respects. A major cause of their confusion is their failure to distinguish between plant variety rights and a restricted list. I explained earlier that plant variety rights enable somebody who produces a new cultivar to take out patent rights and to extract a portion of economic rent accruing to a higher yielding variety. A restricted list prohibits the growing of other than a few specified varieties in a region, a region which may be as large as a whole State or country. Australia already has a restrictive list for the wheat industry. It has had for a number of years. Although the production of varieties not on the approved list is not prohibited by law, varieties grown in regions for which they are not approved are acceptable into the bulk handling systems and to the monopoly buyer, the Australian Wheat Board, only at heavy discounts. We could have-indeed, Australia does have-a restricted list for our major arable farming industry without plant variety rights. Conversely, it is quite possible to have plant variety rights without a restricted list.

The second fallacy proposed by the Lygon Street farmers is that if any plant variety rights legislation were passed all farmers would be forced to buy seeds from the monopolists, who would soon gain control of seed production. That is wrong because most farmers keep their own seed and would be able to continue doing so. They could also keep indefinitely the seed of the varieties they are already growing. A refinement of the multinational conspiracy theory is that these monopolists, who are assumed to be multinationals, I suppose to increase the scare power of the theory, would then devote all their attention to producing hybrid seeds which would germinate or ripen only if they were treated with vast quantities of poisonous chemicals. That was supplemented frequently by allegations that as soon as plant variety rights legislation was passed in the United States of America something like 365 small seed companies were taken over by the said multinationals in the space of about 15 minutes. I have been able to find absolutely no evidence to support that allegation. The real point I want to make is that hybrids either lose their hybrid vigour-that is, their superior yield-in succeeding generations or they produce seed which is sterile. The producer of hybrids is in physical control of the parent stock and is therefore able to extract as large a proportion of the economic rent as he or she feels inclined to try to extract with or without plant variety rights. In other words, plant variety rights are irrelevant to such an argument.

Such is the quality of the argument which has been advanced by the Lygon Street farmers that they have embarrassed all the informed people who have had valid objections to this legislation and have opposed it. I will deal briefly with some of those valid objections. There is a very real fear-I believe a justifiable fear-that if plant variety rights legislation is passed there will be, particularly under a government such as the present one, a serious decline in funding of the public institutions which have traditionally carried out plant breeding work in Australia. I give one example already of the present Government 's propensity to do that. For more than a year the Australian Wheat Growers Federation has agreed to an increase in the grower research levy on wheat deliveries. Such levies are matched on a dollar-for-dollar basis by Commonwealth money, by taxpayers' funds. Despite such an agreement from the industry and, indeed, a request from the Australian Wheat Growers Federation to the Government that the levy and implicitly the Commonwealth matching grant be increased to finance expanded wheat research, the Government, or the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) at least-it may not have reached the Government-has declined to act, and for the time being the issue has been buried.

This contrasts starkly with the propensity of Ministers of this Government with agricultural interests to throw away huge amounts of taxpayers' money on wasteful tax rorts and similar areas of expenditure. The amount involved in the proposed increase in wheat research for the Commonwealth is at most something less than $2m. It demonstrates the meanness of this Government when it comes to making public funds available for what is almost certainly worthwhile economic agricultural research.

The second objection does not necessarily apply to all plant variety rights legislation, but it applies to the type of plant variety rights legislation provided for in this Bill. The only test imposed for the registration of a new variety is that it be genetically distinct or distinctive from varieties already registered and that it have reasonable genetic purity. There is no requirement for performance testing. Given that, two things are likely to happen. Firstly, high pressure publicity, promotion of a new variety, is likely to take precedence over quality. High pressure publicity and promotion will become a substitute for superior quality, and it will encourage the commercial firms which may become involved in the industry to indulge in what some plant breeders call cosmetic breeding-that is, producing strains which are identifiable as being different from other strains but which do not necessarily have any economic advantages.

Even if there were provision for testing in this legislation prior to registration and release and if a number of institutions became involved in plant breeding, as supporters of the Bill have suggested, the testing procedures would be quite expensive-indeed, at least for the grain industry, so expensive that it seems to me that it would preclude the establishment of a privately funded and based industry. For the reasons I stated earlier, Australian wheat farmers buy seed once only, as a rule-at least until they have discarded the variety. They do not then buy large quantities. They may buy a bag or two bags of a new variety, which can, of course, as anyone who knows anything about wheat growing will know, very quickly be bulked up into very large areas. Indeed, it is possible to pinch a couple of heads and stick them in one's pocket and, provided that one grows it twice in one year in one's garden, it is possible to bulk that up to several thousand acres in matter of a couple of years. So very small quantities will be purchased, and the higher the unit price charged by those who, it is suggested would produce seed grain, obviously the smaller the quantity that would be bought. If, on top of that, it was required that expensive testing be undertaken prior to registration and release, that just seems to remove any possibility that cereal grain seed would be produced in the way in which supporters of the Bill suggest.

Finally, on the question whether plant breeding ought to be concentrated and ought to remain in the public sector, as it is and always has been in Australia, or whether it should be partially or wholly transferred to the private sector, I guess to some extent that it is a matter of ideological preference. It is no secret that the preference in the party that I represent, other things being equal, would be that it remain in the public sector. But apart from ideological preference, there is another good reason for it remaining substantially or entirely in the public sector.

Looking at the realities of Australian agriculture, and in particular the fact that our broad-acre farming industries seed is purchased once only by farmers, we believe that to the extent that private plant breeding developed at all it would concentrate on cosmetic breeding and high pressure salemanship and promotion as a substitute for quality. In other words, it is likely to be less efficient than the present breeding arrangements within the public sector. I hasten to add that I do not exclude the possibility that they are not as efficient as they could be or that they are without fault. But the very strong probability is that they are more efficient than an alternative source of seed supply within the private sector would be.

For all those reasons, therefore, the Labor Party has a great number of doubts about this Bill. However, we are not implacably opposed to it. We are willing to listen to further argument. We believe that it is necessary that a proper searching investigation into Australia'a plant breeding needs and deficiencies be conducted, including an examination of the question of all alternatives and the implications of existing plant variety rights matters. Above all, if such legislation is ever to be passed, it must meet Australian agricultural requirements. I move:
Leave out all words after 'that', and insert:
'this Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on National Resources'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I readily support the Plant Variety Rights Bill . Like the previous speaker, Senator Walsh, I believe that confusion, odd statements and outright misrepresentations have been features of this matter coming to fruition. Before I go into that, I wish to define how I see plant variety rights-that is, the right to protection of a species and the right to receive a royalty if the variety is believed to have sufficient commercial value to warrant the protection.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to realise that the rights will only apply provided the owner of a plant species makes application and pays the appropriate fee. TALK.START.PARA: —The schedules include varieties of sweet corn and green beans. It is absolutely imperative for Tasmania to have these if we are to build up our agricultural pursuits in the vegetable area. The lists contain several varieties of fruit such as nectarines, cool climate grapes, strawberries, apples and blackcurrants. All those products are very important to Tasmania. At present they are not available. The list was compiled on an Australia-wide basis. I have seen some of these varieties of products. I have been to some of the places where they are growing. I can certainly confirm that they are not available to us at the present time. I repeat that by and large it is more important that we should have access to those varieties at the moment than to try to produce new varieties in place. We need to remember that there is absolutely no limitation on people growing whatever seeds they like. It does not matter whether they are new seeds or old seeds. People may sell them however they like, where they like and for whatever they can get for them. This is the position under the present scheme and it is not changed one iota under the plant variety rights legislation .

SPEECH.PARA: I too have received considerable correspondence. I have answered in detail well over 300 letters. I too have never had so much correspondence on any subject as I have had on plant variety rights. I have followed very closely the various matters that have been raised in those letters. Whenever any specific allegation has been made I have written back and said 'I am interested in plant variety rights. I appreciate the point you have put. Will you please submit the source of your information? Will you please supply me with the evidence that you have to back it up?'. I have never received a reply to one of those letters. Not once has anybody tried to support some of the wilder claims that have been made. Never once have I had one piece of evidence that would support them.

The plant variety rights business started about 52 years ago. As of now approximately 22 countries, most of which are fairly major countries, have plant variety rights schemes. At the moment five countries are in much the same position as we are here-that is, they are on the verge of moving into plant variety rights. There is a need for urgency. There are many holdups in our agriculture which plant variety rights would assist. Australia needs the new development. We need the new industries that go with it. We especially need the new varieties of plants. At the moment we are prevented from achieving this by the lack of legislation.

I have done a little plant breeding. I know what it takes in the way of time and understanding. I know the very poor ratio of good plants to bad plants that anybody is likely to get. In the areas in which I was interested I fully appreciate that there would be no likelihood of registering the sorts of plants that most people grow for decorative purposes, purely and simply because the cost involved would not justify the time needed to be taken. The proportion of seeds that is ever likely to be registered will always be very small. Recently I went to the UK to have a look at the work that is being done. I went to four research stations in England. I met many of the breeders and talked to the people involved. I was informed that in 1964 there were 10 breeders registered in England and that now there are 23. The amount of money going into plant breeding has increased by 500 per cent in five years. Of course, the results match the expenditure. While I was there I looked at wheat, barley and various other products. I was interested to find that the main variety of barley which is grown in Australia-a variety called Proctor-has been superseded in England for between 15 and 20 years. We still use Proctor as the No. 1 Australian barley . That indicates how far out of date we are already.

There has been a lot of talk about the increase which has occurred in cropping in England. People with whom I have spoken have said that it is ridiculous to claim that plant variety rights have resulted in an increased crop, that is due to better insecticides and so on. The scientists who are involved say that the wheat yield has increased by 94 per cent since plant variety rights were introduced. Of this, they attribute 56 per cent as being due to the new varieties. There is not one variety of wheat in common usage in England now which is more than seven years old. For barley the growth rate has increased by 67 per cent since plant variety rights came in, 32 per cent of which is assessed as being due to plant improvement. The lack of legislation in relation to fruit varieties, pasture varieties, and vegetables in particular is holding Australia back. We need to get access to these new varieties. In fact, we are falling behind in some of these areas, and we are falling behind for two reasons. Firstly, we do not pay for what is available. Other people have it; they are prepared to sell it. We are not prepared to pay so we do not get it, and we do not give them the protection that goes with that. Secondly, we provide no protection for our local people; and so in most cases they do not see why this is necessary.

I should like to quote one particular case. In Tasmania, one of the major primary industry crops is poppies. The poppy we grow in Tasmania is a species that has been totally developed by Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd. It is nothing like the poppy the company started with 20 years ago. This has been achieved by years and years of very expensive cultivation, to the stage where it is now an absolutely outstanding example of what can be done by breeding. Yet in that case the company has no protection at all. The one company that is in total competition with Glaxo owes it nothing for the many years of research that went into producing that item.

Tasmania has a great capacity to extend in primary industry. It has an ideal climate for a wide variety of plants. It has a wide variety of conditions and has a natural quarantine factor, which is a great help in the development of livestock and agriculture. The Tasmanian Government wants plant variety rights, as do the Department of Primary Industry, the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, and the processors. To the best of my knowledge, there is absolutely no one in Tasmania associated with agriculture in any meaningful way and representative of any reasonable group who has brought any objection to me.

On the Australian scene, we are now in the position of having received approval for plant variety rights from every State and Territory but one. We have received the approval of all national rural organisations, including the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Wheat Growers Federation, the Australian United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association, the Australian Seed Producers Federation, the Australian Nurserymen's Association Ltd, and the Australian Seed Industry Association.

One area in regard to plant variety rights that has always worried me quite a lot is the matter of quarantine. While we do not have plant variety rights, we run a grave risk that material that is stolen or brought overseas and smuggled through Customs could have very serious effects in Australia if it fails to go through the normal checks that are applicable to material that is brought in legally. The lack of legislation unquestionably creates smuggling, and its existence would make smuggling unnecessary. I believe this is terribly important , and I think it is one of the areas to which we need to apply ourselves.

One of the points quite often raised with me is the matter of cost. I could not enumerate the bogies I have heard about cost and the fact that we could expect the price of seeds to rise two or three times. I think it needs to be said that nobody will pay unless they believe they are getting something for their money. They will not pay enormous amounts of money for nothing. I accept Senator Walsh' s point of view about promotion, but I do not think people will get caught or pay out large amounts of money without ensuring that they get something for it. People will pay only for what they believe is value. The price will be regulated by the result. Certainly I would be happy to pay more for a better variety. If we really need a better variety, we need one which will suit our particular requirements.

I suppose it is all tied in with the question of merit. Merit, I think, is a concept of no value whatsoever. Merit to me and merit to somebody else may be entirely different. If I need something for a particular purpose, I might have an entirely different set of criteria. For instance, in England I saw growing several varieties of raspberries that I wished we had in Australia. Some of these raspberries were growing seven feet to eight feet tall and were ideal for mechanical harvesting. While I was at one of these research establishments, the head of a jelly company arrived. His company manufactured fresh fruit jelly. He was particularly interested in seeking a variety of raspberry with an excessively high proportion of juice which could be harvested mechanically. Varieties of that type were available, but the establishment was also growing varieties of exactly the opposite type, shorter in height, firmer in fruit, to be used for a different purpose altogether. Whether the fruits were to be used for jam or jelly or for the fresh fruit market, this establishment was producing several entirely different sorts of raspberries. I venture to suggest that the merit involved would be determined by the person who wished to buy them according to the particular purpose for which they were required.

I also visited another establishment where wheat trials were being carried out. There were 46 different varieties of new wheats in a row, but the particular item being tested was not the grain at all. The grain was virtually the same in every case and basically the yield was very similar. The establishment was trying to determine different straws and different amounts of flag to be used in areas where there might be a wind problem, where there might be stones and there was a need to cut further up from the ground, where by getting close to the ground they might have induced extra rust, or problems of that sort. Merit is something that the purchaser alone can determine. There is no way in which we can include in legislation the sorts of items that Senator Walsh had in mind. We cannot say that we do not like a variety that grows seven feet tall, that we prefer a variety that grows six feet tall, or something of that sort. I believe it is a matter that the marketplace in Australia will determine, in exactly the same way as it has determined it in every other country which now has plant variety rights. I am unable to find any country where merit is regarded as being necessary to provide details for this range of climatic and other conditions. It does come down to the national lists. I think the biggest single confusion I have found is in the difference between a national list and plant variety rights . The two things are totally different and the reasons for them are totally different. I am pleased to say that at this stage we are having nothing to do with a national list.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the same as Senator Walsh's restricted list?

—Yes. I should like now to take up one or two of the points I have gathered from correspondence. When I found that many of the questions were obviously being circulated by people or groups I decided, in view of the fact that the people who were writing to me could not give me the information I was asking them for, to put three questions on notice in the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The questions read as follows-
Senator Archer asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry upon notice on 6 May 1982:
What evidence is there that a section of plant breeders may promote varieties needing abnormal support from fertilizers and chemicals?
Senator Chaney: The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I have seen no such evidence and I do not believe any exists.

From time to time the assertion has been made that once PVR is introduced breeders will breed plants which will require abnormally high quantities of fertilizers or chemicals, or require specific chemicals available only through the same plant breeding company.

There is no doubt in my mind that in their breeding programs, breeders will place a high priority on resistance to disease and insect pests. To deliberately adopt the opposite course would be commercially foolish. No company is going to waste time (and breeding is a very costly process) in developing varieties which are less resistant to diseases or insects than varieties already available to the public.
No farmers or gardeners are going to buy varieties which require more fertilizer, or special inputs, unless it pays them to do so.
Senator Archer asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry upon notice on 6 May 1982:
Are the Plant Diversity Protection Committee's claims that there are thirteen ways of avoiding PVR correct?
Senator Chaney: The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The possibilities proposed by the Plant Diversity Protection Committee for avoiding PVR are extremely limited in providing rewards or protection for plant breeders. None of the aternatives suggested provide the comprehensive protection which will be provided by the PVR Scheme.

The various non-statutory provisions proposed by the Committee, such as the use of hybrids specialised production techniques and other commercial arrangements give plant breeders a limited advantage only. Most of these arangements are already in use today. Clearly they do not meet industry needs, otherwise they would be no demand for a PVR Scheme.

Equally, the proposed statutory provisions, such as the use of trademarks, resort to common law and inventor's certificates, are limited in effect and do not provide the comprehensive protection which would be available under PVR.

PVR is the only system which will legally protect the proprietary rights of breeders to new varieties they have developed, and which will also enable Australia to gain commercial access to varieties protected overseas.
Senator Archer asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry upon notice on 6 May 1982:
What levels of royalties and other charges are being made in other countries where PVR is in operation?
Senator Chaney: The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

A plant variety right gives the holder control over the sale of plants and reproductive material of that variety. It also entitles him to license others to sell plants and reproductive material of that variety.

As far as I am aware, this is the basis of the right in all countries where Plant Variety Rights (PVR) schemes exist. It is a matter for the holder of the right to make a commercial judgment as to the premium that he considers the market is prepared to pay because it considers his variety superior to other varieties.
The royalties, or premiums, being made in various countries at any particular time are a function of the market forces existing at that time.

It is important to remember that farmers and gardeners will also make judgments about the seeds and plants they are purchasing and it is highly unlikely that a premium will be paid for a variety if that variety cannot return the investment.

The question referred to 'other charges'. In PVR schemes in other countries there are specific charges related to the granting and maintenance of the right. The level of fees varies from country to country but generally amount to something under $1,000 per variety registered.
In the USA, for example, the fees are $US250 application, $US250 search and a further $US250 when the certificate is issued. That is, a total of $US750.

In New Zealand and the United Kingdom there are different levels of fees for different categories of species. In New Zealand, for example, fees for agricultural crops and vegetables amount to a total of $NZ750 and the annual renewal fee is $NZ50.

In the United Kingdom the application fee for cereals and potatoes, for example is #220. In addition, a test fee in the first year of #385 (slightly less in subsequent years) is charged and an annual renewal fee of #165 in the second year (increasing in subsequent years) is charged.
