TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Walsh in that I do not think the multinationals are dominating the seed industry in places such as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Poland, Israel and the likes of those. I do not see them as being the hotbeds of multinational profiteering. To think that it would be any different here or there is certainly incorrect. I saw a letter in, I think, the National Farmer which said it would be illegal to grow non-approved varieties. Again, this is absolute rubbish, and I think that needs to be said. The assertion that it is unfair to the Third World and that we are grinding the Filipinos to death-which is what somebody told me-again is absolute nonsense. If the First, Second or Third World countries can see that there is some advantage in using better varieties and in having better research, they will do so. If they find it will cost them more to achieve nothing, they certainly will not do so. I do not see them as being any different from anybody else in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the monopoly question whereby it is alleged that people will get these varieties and hold on to them tightly. The Bill provides that reasonable quantities at reasonable prices must be provided if there is a demand for them. I have no doubt that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances would be able to establish what reasonable quantities and reasonable amounts would be.

I would like to comment on a couple of matters that worry Senator Walsh. I do not see that the level of government funding is a point at all. So far as plant variety rights, and the legislation that goes with it are concerned, government funding will be provided, as it is for every other area, whether it be education , defence or whatever, depending on the overall budgetary situation. Whether the present Government is doing this or whether the Opposition if in government were to do it, there is no way that the situation would be any different. What I do say is that anybody who is governing the country will at all times endeavour to see that the money that is provided will achieve the greatest possible result. I believe there are plenty of ways in which the Government can be involved, which may not entail it operating the whole system on its own. In the United Kingdom I saw the system that I would certainly recommend here. The Government research stations over there produce a variety of items. I noticed, for instance, the Cambridge strawberries, which are marvellous and which I would like to have here . When the Cambridge research station produces those strawberries and gets them to the marketable stage, it calls tenders for the merchandising of them. The producer of the variety, as the Government, does not get into the commerce area, but passes it off to where it is dealt with by people who are in that business. It is a happy relationship. I think there are all sorts of ways in which if the effort needs to be increased it can be done by perhaps tax incentives, bonuses, joint ventures or whatever. I see no way that it can be claimed and proved that because of plant variety rights legislation the amount of money used by the Government in research would be lowered.

Senator Walsh's other point is one that I cannot argue with. We on this side of the chamber do not believe that private ownership is bad. We do not believe that private ownership is to be avoided. It may even be that we believe a little bit the other way, that public ownership is not to be engaged in unless the private sector is unable to cope adequately with it. I believe we could get an increase in government funding if the system were better. I repeat that it is absolutely imperative that we have access to the varieties overseas. I repeat that it is important that we utilise all the resources there are in Australia, that we encourage Australians to get into this area to the best of their ability and that we try to sell to the other people. There are enormous demands from overseas for things like grass seeds. We could produce millions and millions of dollars worth of grass seeds and sell them overseas if we had this sort of legislation. I ask the Opposition to reconsider this question of deferring the Bill. It is part of government business. We would like to get the legislation going. We want to ensure that the people of Australia get the advantage of it as quickly as they can. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Plant Variety Rights Bill 1982 has indeed been, as Senator Walsh and Senator Archer have indicated, the basis of some massive misrepresentations. However, unlike Senator Archer I do not limit those misrepresentations to one side of the debate. In fact both sides of the debate have been fairly prominent in attempting, as they go through this legislation, to misrepresent the arguments which are being presented and to paint yet again in this country a black and white picture of anything which we try to debate seriously. I presume that one eventually becomes accepting of this type of situation. Nevertheless it is galling that an area which is complex, difficult and important should yet again be painted into a black and white context.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill to send this Bill to a committee, and the Australian Democrats will be supporting that amendment. I wish to speak on the basis of why we would support such an amendment. I believe that if we wish the matter to be referred to a committee we should not at this stage rehearse our arguments and propositions for and against but rather we should outline why we are objecting to the Bill and why we believe that a committee investigation of the Bill would be of use to the community.

Unfortunately, in this debate we have had an omnibus approach to primary industry. To many people the words 'primary industry' mean only one thing. Primary industry is thought of as a unitary operation. Nothing could be further from the truth. Indeed, in terms of market organisation in this country the wheat industry is as distinct from the cherry industry as it is from the car industry. Senator Archer unfortunately did not allude to the intricacies of the marketing operations of the various items he was discussing. One could very well point out, for example, that while it is not unlawful to grow certain varieties of wheat it certainly is unlawful to sell them. Why anybody would want to grow wheat he could not sell I have no idea.

I believe that the effects of this legislation must be considered in relation to the overall economy. It is in this area that I am extremely critical of the Government. This legislature is being treated yet again by the Executive to a botched up job in terms of argumentation and is being asked to pass a piece of legislation without being supplied with information. The Executive somehow considers that by remaining silent for a year it has effectively stimulated public debate. Goodness knows why it should consider that, but it does. Not only that, but the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has castigated the States for not doing more in terms of public debate when indeed the legislation is before this House. This House and this Government have a responsibility to promote public debate, and that does not mean remaining silent for a year. It means providing information to the members of the public so that they can talk about it, so that they can be informed about it and so that there can be lively, detailed and informed debate within the community. That has not occurred. This Government sees absolutely no necessity to give this legislature information upon which it may make a decision whether to pass this piece of legislation.

I allude to one consideration which I believe is most important-that is, the effect of plant variety rights legislation on the economy. I would like to know what the Government has done about projecting the effects of PVR legislation on our rural industry. I assume that if the Government has been doing its work correctly detailed information would have been available and the Government would have been able to produce some of the things to which Senator Archer referred; that is, the estimated cost rises and availability of seed, the flow- on results in terms of food costs and the like. Such effects may be minimal or non-existent. However, I believe, and I presume Senator Archer would agree, that this information should be produced by the Government and its Department for public consumption and, if not for public consumption, certainly for consumption of this chamber. Therefore, I would like information on the projections that the Government has made in this area. If those projections are not forthcoming, I believe one would be compelled to take a much more cynical attitude and suggest that the reason they have not been circulated is that they do not exist and that the Government is indulging yet again in a range of arm waving assertions on the basis that the Minister for Primary Industry resides in the House of Representatives and feels absolutely no pressure upon him to engage in any detailed informed debate.

The arguments that have been put are in fact detailed. I do not intend to allude to the whole range of arguments raised by Senator Archer. I presume they were raised because they were contained in the 300 letters he has had to answer. The straw people whom the honourable senator stood up and knocked down are indeed just that-straw. Such argument need not detain us.

I wish to refer to one matter which the honourable senator raised and the very simplistic line of attempting to make comparisons between ourselves and overseas . On the receipt of information in respect of a detailed area one of the first things one has to be very careful about is making comparisons between ourselves and overseas operations, particularly in the primary industry area and particularly if one does not also take into account a whole range of factors which may influence the final result, which may have a bearing on the final result and which indeed may have a larger bearing on the final result than the particular item to which one is dedicated and wishes to push.

Senator Archer talked about a burst of improvements in the United Kingdom in the last decade due to the release of semi-dwarf varieties of wheat. The facts of the matter are that the International Wheat and Maize Improvements Centre in Mexico was the main cause of those improvements. We did not experience an enormous boost, despite the fact that the International Wheat and Maize Improvement Centre came by all the vastly improved varieties released in the United Kingdom as a result of work which had been done in Australia by Australians. In other words, through that international centre, the United Kingdom gained improved varieties of wheat for which we received no royalties. However I must point out that I think the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation deserves some praise. We have sought to diversify to other countries the types of advances that we make in this country. I believe that is a perfectly laudable objective. The world in general ought to look at maximising the resources that are available from our rural products. I believe that the results of our work should be made as freely available as possible to other countries. We have done that. Australia should take credit for that. As a country we have been a major contributor to the centre and a major reason for its success. We are a major contributor in that regard to the success of wheat crops around the world. If Australia's contribution is not acknowledged all the facts are not being put on the table.

People who have looked at the situation in the United Kingdom, as presumably Senator Archer did when he visited that country recently, know that that country has a system of very high inputs in its farming operation. Indeed, reliable estimates put inputs at around the $200 mark per acre. The United Kingdom can operate under that type of high input farming. However, Australia has not done so in the past, it is not doing so at present and in terms of the economics of most of the broadacre crops it is hardly likely to do so in the future. A lack of statistics in this country does not enable us to make firm estimates of the cost per acre but certainly the guesstimates that have been made by reliable people with whom I have had contact put it nowhere near the $200 mark. If that is the case, we are comparing unlike items and any comparison of unlike items must necessarily fall down. We have to get our base level and argue on that level. Without doing that we are talking nonsense.

It is worth noting in this regard, as I have already done, that the Australian Wheat Board strictly controls our operations and does not in fact allow the types of free ranging operations that seemed to be the basis of Senator Archer's remarks. That is for a very good reason. We wish to maintain a steady marketing operation. I believe the Government also supports this objective through the Federal Council of the Liberal Party did exactly the opposite-but I believe it is hastening to rectify its mistakes in that regard.

Something particularly important in my home State of Queensland is the comparison that must be made in terms of how we go about the operation of storing our seed, again particularly for broadacre crops. In the United Kingdom, the example used by Senator Archer, it is known that about 90 per cent of seed is not stored but is bought from seed merchants. That is due to climatic and economic conditions and partly to historical reasons. In Australia the average figure-I exclude Queensland because a different situation applies-is about 4 per cent. In other words, most farmers store their own seed and sow their own seed. Queensland is different because it has a much more highly developed operation in relation to seed programs and I will come to that in a moment. I also think that it would have been far better for the Commonwealth to look at what is done in Queensland than to press ahead with this legislation, particularly in relation to wheat. The reason for that is that Australia is by no means a unitary country when it comes to primary production. There is an enormous variety of soil and climatic conditions in this country which make invalid comparisons with other countries which have plant variety rights.

I believe it is very difficult, possibly even impossible, for a commercial enterprise to look at profitable operations in relation to these varieties. A commercial enterprise probably would not attempt to do so. For that reason I believe that in Australia, whether this Bill is passed or not, we will rely in large measure on our public institutions to provide the basis of varieties to cope with the soil and climatic conditions. I refer to Queensland which in fact has localised comparative field trials. They have been operating for quite some time. I believe that these trials are absolutely essential. I believe they must continue whether this Bill is passed or not. Not only that, the Commonwealth Government also needs to come in behind that type of operation in a much better and more comprehensive way than it has done in the past, particularly in terms of funding. Only by means of comparative field trials within specified local areas will farmers be fairly confident that the type of seed they are getting will be of benefit to them.

It is not possible, in a large variety of primary industries, to take a punt in relation to the plant or seed variety that one wishes to use. One needs firmly based detailed information. I believe that this particular aspect is of concern, particularly to the small farmer. It has been put, of course, that all the major rural lobby groups support this legislation. I agree with that. That certainly does seem to be the case. If that is the case, one might then go on to argue: Why should we save people from themselves? Our concern is not only for those large groups but also for the small farmer. I believe that the smaller farmers need, and must have guarantees of, protection so that when they actually do use new seed varieties they do so not simply on the basis that it is a commercial proposition, that someone has advertised or put out a prospectus on that particular seed. They rely more heavily, certainly in my State, upon the comparative field trials which are conducted under State auspices. By looking at the results of those trials, in terms of soil quality, climatic conditions and the rainfall that occurred during a specified period, they can feel confident about the commercial judgments they make and what they do with their production. They are not capable of making those estimates if inadequate material is available to them.

I am not decrying the ability of farmers to make those types of choices as some people have suggested. It has nothing to do with that at all. Flourishing in this country, whether those people who are opposed to this recognise it or not, is a fairly massive media industry which, presumably, rests upon the fact that it can sell a product on a fairly inadequate, often contradictory or irrelevant bases. I do not presume that farmers are any more immune to the operation of that fairly high powered industry than anybody else in this community. The reaction of the farmers to whom I have spoken, the people who actually have to get out and earn a living, is this: 'I do not care what you do with the plant variety rights legislation. It is of no benefit to me. It is of no interest to me. But I want those materials. I need to know what that seed will do. I do not care where it comes from so long as the Government can vouch that it is true.'. In other words, they are not going to trust a commercial operation. They want the Department of Primary Industry or the relevant government department to give and to back up those types of assertions. That is what the small farmer wants. That is what the person who has to earn his living wants. When he makes a punt on his seed he has got to see that crop come to fruition. That is what that person wants. The other stuff really does not concern him much at all.

That is the type of thing to which a Senate inquiry should direct its attention . It should investigate what types of guarantees ought to be given to farmers who have to make a living out of this type of operation, quite apart from the aspect of the protection of the seed companies or whatever. It is the farmer who has to make a living who wants to be assured of the quality of the seed. I believe that we should not push them out on their own and say that the Government washes its hands of the whole operation. I do not believe that State governments would do that but I believe also that it is a matter for the Commonwealth Government.

I wish to allude briefly to a range of other matters. I refer to the fact that the Commonwealth obviously, in terms of the third amendment moved in the House of Representatives, sees this as part of a patent law. I think it is interesting timing that the Government should send a reference to the Industrial Property Advisory Committee to look at the patenting operation while it is changing the law under this particular legislation.

There are many other types of objections to this legislation. One matter which I believe is important in terms of plant breeding and has come to light in quite recent operations, indeed only this year, concerns genetic engineering. Enormous advances are being made in that area. I raise this matter because of the legal implications that I can see arising. Some legal implications have already arisen . I allude particularly to cases being dealt with in the United States Supreme Court concerning genetic engineering and factors associated with it. A peripheral case in relation to this-it had some rather interesting implications- was raised in the Irish High Court. The Government has not yet, certainly in anything that I have read, given a detailed response. I would not support a second reading of a Bill unless I could have the Government's considered view in relation to advances which are occurring at the present time and the legal implication of them as projected by the Government's legal officers. One is not asking the impossible. One is merely asking for the considered view of the Government at this particular time in relation to what we already know.

I should now like to turn to a point raised by Senator Archer. I asked Senator Archer where the information came from which he incorporated in Hansard. He did not bother replying to my interjection so I still do not know where it came from . Perhaps the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) may be able to tell me. I see that he is shaking his head so he does not appear to know either. I refer to the only information the Government has put out-the plant variety rights information kit. I put a number of queries to the Department and I acknowledge the Minister's response to them. Information included in the information kit under 'I' concerns the restriction of access to overseas varieties which, of course, is part of the argument being put about this Bill as to whether or not we are losing out in terms of overseas varieties. We have received a document. A variety of items was included in it. Not being a terribly trusting soul in relation to the information given to me by the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Yes, it is; nevertheless I have learnt by bitter experience about trusting the Government in terms of the information it gives me, even in a glossy brochure such as this. Therefore, I made a number of phone calls. I made only four phone calls and then decided that I was wasting my time because, in making those phone calls, I found out the following information. With regard to one of the varieties included, only one request had been forwarded and no reply had ever been received. It was put down as 'denied access'. It does not seem to me to be a reasonable assumption, because somebody failed to reply, that Australia had been denied access because of PVR. After all, the letter may even have got lost in our mail. I do not know why that should have been included in this.

SPEECH.PARA: I decided to press on. I made another phone call about the next variety and found that the request had been refused on the first occasion. I asked: 'Well, did you press the request?' I was learning that one had to press one's requests if they were first refused. But that had not been done. I asked: 'Why not?' and was told: 'We assumed that they wouldn't change their minds.' I asked: 'Why?' There was no response. That is hardly hard evidence of obdurate refusal on the part of overseas companies because of PVR. The situation was becoming interesting. In the next phone call I found that the particular source that had been refused is normally extremely generous in the provision of varieties to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the boom was lower down.

—No, on this one I was not able to find anybody who could help. In fact I tracked down the very division that dealt with it, but nobody had any recollection of a denial ever having been made on that variety. Perhaps the Minister will be able to have a look at this and by the end of the debate give us chapter and verse on it, rather than the sloppy documentation we have received so far. While he is at it, he might also like to look at an area that I did not turn up, that is, the varieties under the heading 'peach'. I was talking to a group of people from the industry who were lobbying me to support PVR, and when I mentioned this fact to them they said: 'Yes, and you also noticed of course that the item under peaches is incorrect?'. I said that I had not noticed . They were lobbying me in favour of the legislation, and they thought it was pretty sloppy that such an item had been circulated to members.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to vote for legislation on the basis of that type of information . Members of the House of Representatives may do so, as we saw with the honey legislation; but it went to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and was pulled off in no time at all when the Committee asked the first obvious question: 'Who wants this?' We have that sort of sloppy documentation from a department, yet it is not responsible. The Minister is the person responsible. I will not vote for legislation unless I have detailed information. Let us have reasonable debate and let us have some information if people want it. When people in the industry, as they have done already, ask me: 'Why are you knocking this back? Why are you delaying this legislation?', I say that I am doing it on the basis that this Government refuses to give to me information to which I am entitled, as an elected senator from Queensland, before I cast my vote. While other members here may take their votes from their party, I have to take personal responsibility for mine. I will not vote for legislation upon which I do not have information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or are given incorrect information.
—Or on which I am given incorrect information, as I have pointed out.
—We are only emulating Diogenes, seeking the truth, aren't we?

—Thank you, Senator. I will press on because I do not think I can say anything in response to that. One of the other items that worries me, and I have spoken about it often in the Senate, is research. I am particularly concerned about the research budget. The Minister has refused-he refused again in his reply in the House of Representatives-to give a categorical assurance that research moneys will not be cut back to our public institutions engaged in research in this area. I believe that the reason he has not given that assurance is fairly obvious: The intention is to cut back. I and most other people who have anything to do with rural industry are particularly concerned about this aspect. It is an extremely important aspect because, even if we had private breeding programs, they would take only end line operations. There is absolutely no reason for them to do other than that. They are commercial operations and they must look to their commercial concerns. That is perfectly laudable and acceptable and I am not criticising companies on that aspect. That is what they are set up to do and what they must do. But in doing that they must be very careful in their research programs that they do not waste money that cannot have a commercial spin-off.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why we fund fundamental research in public institutions. It is only by the funding of public research in this country that we can afford to take a punt . We have taken punts in the past, particularly with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, that have paid off enormously. Anybody who knows anything about fundamental research will know that there is no possibility whatsoever, when undertaking that research, of knowing that what will come out of the research will be of commercial concern. It is just not possible to do that. That is not the nature of research. It is also not the nature of research to close it up. It is not possible. A person must have free access to information and to publications and be able to engage in debate and controversy in the learned journals. He must be able to do that and, with his peers in that area, learn from them and they from him. By that type of operation in the community we all come to know more about the various aspects undertaken by our public institutions. I believe that is fundamental to the whole notion of public research. This Government has failed to give a categorical assurance that that public research will be maintained. It can be given by this Government and must be given by this Government before I will vote for such a Bill.

In conclusion, I say that the reason we will support the Australian Labor Party 's amendment is on the basis that the Government has given incorrect information , and has not given to the Parliament information that we need to enable us to make up our minds; also on the basis of the lack of an informed public debate which would enable everybody within the community to realise what we are contemplating. We are contemplating a piece of legislation that is probably the most important piece of legislation this century for rural areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree with the point that the Plant Variety Rights Bill is a most important piece of agricultural legislation. I have listened with great interest to Senator Macklin's contribution in an effort to determine exactly why the Australian Democrats desire that this important legislation, as they acknowledge, be referred to a committee rather than passed in its present form. As I understood the contribution of Senator Macklin, there were basically three separate reasons. The first was the alleged lack of information, or incorrect information, on certain details. I hope that those aspects will be clarified later in the debate by the Government and, I hope, to the satisfaction of Senator Macklin.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point he made was the lack of informed public debate which, as I understood him, was based on the failure of the Government to give accurate projections. It would appear to me that to ask the Government to give accurate projections as to how many new varieties of plants will come into being as a result of this legislation, or what will be the increasing tonnage of product as a result of it, is an unreal request. The best that can be given by the Government is a reference to experience overseas in the 25-odd countries that have similar legislation and the beneficial effect of the legislation in those countries. An examination of that, and it is something I will refer to in my short contribution, would indicate that there are considerable advantages in passing this legislation, notwithstanding the impossibility of producing precise projections as to the ultimate result. I would like to think that, after I have been able to refer to some of those experiences, Senator Macklin might be persuaded to the advantages of the legislation.

The third point is one that I certainly would not want to dispute and I am sure that the Government would not want to dispute. I refer to the desirability, in fact the necessity, of fundamental research in all sorts of areas in academic institutions. It has been the submission of the Government in presenting this Bill and in speeches in the other place, which Senator Macklin would have no doubt read, that fundamental research will not be in any way inhibited by this legislation, that rather it provides an additional method by which benefit can come to the rural community through the likely availability of greater varieties , and increased quality, of plants. If Senator Macklin is convinced on the basis of my few words, and the second reading of speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), that fundamental research will not be detrimentally inhibited by this Bill I hope he will be satisfied on the three objections that he has raised on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I hope that by the end of this debate the Australian Democrats may be prepared to reconsider, and pass the legislation. It is clearly in Australia's interest to ensure that all available means are utilised to increase the potential of our agricultural industry. As a major world food producer that is also Australia's responsibility.

Over the last 40 years pasture yields have been determined principally by the development of land husbandry techniques; that is, the increased use of pesticides, chemical nutrients and mechanisation. All have made significant contributions to increased productivity. It has been really over the last few years that the use of new and improved varieties of seeds and plants has provided a means of increasing yields and has become particularly significant in horticulture, fodder crop and cereal production-even in ornamental plant production. For those in the plant breeding industry it is now a time of great excitement and rapid change. I refer to such men as Hugh Roberts, a former Nuffield scholar, who studied the British cereal seed industry in 1977 and who points to the appearance of crops that only a generation ago were a dream-barley that will grow in sand watered by sea water, peas with no leaves to make them easier to harvest, and high lysine grains requiring no protein supplement for feeding to animals, all of which he states are at an advanced level of development. Mr Roberts described plant breeding as the new boom industry of the world, one that is clean, does not pollute and shows positive production growth. The concern of Mr Roberts and others in the industry is that we are being left behind in a world of change.

The Government has a responsibility to ensure adequate investment in plant breeding research. But that responsibility does not have to depend solely on direct government involvement in the form of public funding or public collection of levies for such research. Legislative action to confer property rights on plant breeders represents a means of encouraging private investment in research. That is one of the aims of this Bill-not to affect detrimentally public research activity but rather to introduce a means of inducing and encouraging private investment in this area of important research. There is nothing new in the concept of plant variety rights. As I indicated when I commenced, some 25 countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States of America and New Zealand, have legislation of a similar type. The Bill establishes a system of plant variety rights that is broadly similar to the legislation in such countries. In essence, it enables the granting of patent rights to breeders of a new plant or seed variety. The scheme is voluntary. The rights will be granted for new varieties only. Existing seed and plant types will not be included in the scheme.

I submit that implementation can be expected to bring significant benefits to farmers, horticulturalists and orchardists. The holder of the rights for the first time will have the means to realise returns from persons selling new varieties registered under the scheme. Thus the prerequisite for increased private investment activity in the seed breeding industry will have been met. But we are also being left behind because of the reluctance of overseas breeders to release seed for testing and use under Australian conditions without patent protection. Progressively, implementation of this Bill will overcome that hurdle . Therefore, its ultimate objective is to provide improved seed varieties which will lead to higher yields and greater productivity, with consequent benefits to consumers both here and overseas.

Overseas experience has tended to confirm the important function performed by plant variety rights legislation in the generation of private investment activity in the seed breeding industry. I wish to concentrate on that aspect for just a few moments. A study by the United Kingdom Institute of Agricultural Botany shows that between 1947 and 1977 wheat yields in the United Kingdom increased by 94 per cent and barley yields by 67 per cent. Of the 94 per cent increase in wheat yields, 56 per cent was due to improved varieties of wheat. Of the increased barley yield of 67 per cent, 32 per cent was due to improved varieties of barley. When examining these figures Mr P. W. Murphy, the Controller of Plant Variety Rights in the United Kingdom, noted that the increase in yield over the last 10 years-bearing in mind that the first full year of operation of the legislation in that country was 1966-represents nearly half of the total yield increase; also that in the same 10 years a large part of the yield increase resulted from the use of new varieties of seeds.

Of course, that in itself does not prove the contribution played by the United Kingdom plant variety rights legislation. But going back to 1960, Mr Murphy has pointed out that the presence of commercial plant breeders in the major agricultural crops was virtually non-existent. He said that there had then been little possibility of the private sector breeder obtaining any return on his investment, particularly in the easily reproduced crops; that, therefore it was not surprising that only state breeders were active in the agricultural crops sector. However, he points out that since full implementation of the legislation the number of plant breeding firms in the United Kingdom has increased to 23 and that there has been a continuing increase in the number of varieties being brought forward for protection-by 1978, exceeding 480 in number, in the area of agriculture. He indicates that investment in plant breeding is estimated by the British Association of Plant Breeders to have increased in the last five years by more than 500 per cent Therefore what is being seen is a decided widening of seed varieties available to the English farmer, with substantially increased yields in tandem with higher levels of private investment activity in the British seed breeding industry. That is what we desire, and anticipate as flowing from this Bill when it becomes law.

Mr Roberts, to whom I referred earlier, points out that maize is the highest yielding forage crop in the United Kingdom, but 30 years ago was not grown. Now the maize area moves north by five miles a year purely as a result of plant breeders developing better cold country crops. He gives also the example of sugarbeet. In 1950 it took 445 man hours to grow one hectare, but by 1976 this took only 81 man hours, which he largely attributes to the development by plant breeders of a mono-germ beet. Other examples are dwarf cherry and apple trees, all of whose fruit is within reach, better fleshed nectarines and rape seed with disease resistance. He attributes all of these advances to plant breeding. Of equal importance to the need to generate private commercial activity in the seed breeding industry is the desire to obtain access to seed varieties not currently available due to the absence of plant variety rights legislation in Australia. The Australian Agricultural Council Working Party in its 1976 report cited specific instances in which grapes from Germany, rape seed from France, perennial rye grass, cherries and barley from the United Kingdom, garden beans, cotton, strawberries, pome fruit, peaches, nectarines and apricots from the United States are all being refused entry.

I will quote from the publication since I was not given permission to incorporate it in Hansard earlier this afternoon. On page 2 of the publication, under the heading 'Closer Economic Relations with New Zealand', it states:

Since CER first arose the Vegetable Council has been involved with the Departments of Primary Industry and Trade in Canberra. It was apparent that unless a positive and active role was established, the vegetable industry may have been disadvantaged. Through the co-operation of Senator Archer and Senator Tate meetings were arranged in Tasmania with the New Zealand Consul General, Mr. B. Dolan, senior officers of the Department of Trade and the New Zealand High Commission Office.
These meetings and close co-operation from the Department of Primary Industry, especially Dick Coutts, have ensured-
Those are the operative words-
that the final CER agreements for vegetables do not adversely affect Tasmania.

I do not wish to question that judgment. The article goes on to say that the Vegetable Council is presently concerned with the finalisation of legislative details on anti-dumping, et cetera. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the unexpected announcements in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was the tax on certain bank transactions. According to Mr Howard the tax will come into effect on 1 January next year. The legislation has not yet been brought before the Parliament so in some ways we are guessing at what the legislation may contain. What we do know is that debits to bank accounts by cheque or like payments will be subject to tax. Four rates of tax will apply. These are 10c for debits of less than $100, 25c for debits of $100 to $499, 50c for debits of $500 to $4,999, and $1 for amounts over $5,000. I will be talking about cash withdrawals this evening but debits cover many things including cheques written, direct debits from interest payments payable to the bank, transfers to other accounts, bank charges and cash withdrawals.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention to debate the legislation before it is introduced. However, I do make a plea on behalf of pensioners that they not have bank taxes taken from their limited incomes. No doubt a number of people will be critical of the new tax when it comes into operation on 1 January but one group in particular has voiced its concern to me. I refer to the pensioners. Many pensioners have their pensions paid directly into a bank account. They do this so that their pension payments will not be tampered with before they receive them. So many cheques have disappeared from letter boxes that some pensioners believe that the best way they can safeguard their payments is to have them paid into a bank account. Does this mean that withdrawals by these pensioners from their accounts will attract a bank transaction tax? It would be the mark of an insensitive government to bring down legislation like that. Those in our community who are solely dependent on a government benefit for their livelihood should not have to be burdened with a tax simply because they want to keep their money secure.

Charges of 10c or 25c may not seem much to a government and they may not seem much to some of us here but to pensioners every cent has a real meaning. I am fearful that if this tax is payable by pensioners some of them will adopt the hazardous course of hoarding cash. Such a course is hazardous because losses can occur through such things as fire or flood but it also invites theft, sometimes accompanied by violence. Thus I make a plea to the Government to ensure that when the legislation is brought before the Parliament it is framed in such a way that pensioners who have their pensions paid into a bank account are not caught up in a web of bank transaction taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been two speakers in the adjournment debate. I acknowledge Senator Watson's gracious reference to Senator Archer. I am sure, however, that all honourable senators would have understood that his earlier reference to Senator Tate was a reference which arose out of an interjection and was not in any sense meant to suggest the exclusion of any honourable senator, whether from Tasmania or elsewhere, from having an interest in closer economic relations with New Zealand .

SPEECH.PARA: The matter raised by Senator Colston affects pensioners. He suggested that there should be an exemption for pensioners with respect to the proposal to tax bank transactions. The proposal will not touch the great number of pensioners who operate directly by receipt of a cheque and the cashing of that cheque. That sort of transaction will not in any way be affected by what is proposed. Nor will it affect those pensioners who arrange to have their pension cheques paid to an account which is other than a cheque account because the proposal relates only to debit entries resulting from cheques written or direct debits for interest and so on. It applies only to accounts with banks that are subject to operation by cheque or like payment instrument. So we are dealing with a limited number of the pensioner population-namely, those who operate cheque accounts-who will be subject to additional charges. The amount of additional charges is really comparable with the sorts of charges to which cheques have been subject for many years. The most common cheques written undoubtedly will be in the less than $100 category and they will attract a rate of tax of 10c. Cheques of $100 to $499 will attract a rate of 25c. So the actual amount of that imposition will be relatively small.

I note the point made by Senator Colston. I seriously doubt whether it would be administratively feasible to make the sort of exception that he has mentioned because that would require the banks really to segregate all pensioners' accounts from other accounts. I shall ensure that the matter is examined, but my preliminary reaction or response to what Senator Colston has said is that it would be impractical to follow the course that he suggested. I shall, however, have the matter examined, but without wishing in any way to raise an expectation that I would be able to respond positively to his suggestion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
